text:
excellent!! i browned ground beef, drained the fat, used 3 Tbsp per pound of meat and i added 1/2 Tbsp flour to the seasoning and mixed thoroughly before dusting the meat with it. i added 2/3 cup of water, mixed it up with the ground beef and let it simmer down. would be great with shredded beef or chicken too.it is def hotter than the packaged stuff, so if you don't like hot, would reccommend cutting the red pepper flakes. it is salty too. don't substitute sea salt for table salt. it is not an even swap. i did cut the sea salt down slightly...i am making a huge batch of this, sealing it in mason jars with my foodsaver and giving as gifts for christmas. thanks for sharing. i will never go back to packaged mix!!

text:
This is a fantastic seasoning recipe! Like others have mentioned, no more seasoning packets for me. The flavor was so much richer. I didn't tell anyone of the change (I cook for a family of 10) and got lots of excellent compliments. I did receive one complaint about the dish I made, but it came from from a very picky young man who thinks that Taco Bell is authentic Mexican food. :-)  After the first time I used this recipe, I made up a large batch of seasoning to have on hand. It was so easy since I had all of the spices in my pantry anyway. I found that 2 *very* heaping tablespoons of the seasoning equals about one regular seasoning packet. My family likes things a little spicy though, so two regular tablespoons would probably be sufficient.

(I would however suggest maybe just the 1 tsp. of cumin).  We figured out that 21/2 - 3 tablespoons = one 1.25 oz. packet, which I will NEVER go back to!  Thanks so much Bill!

country:
None
text:
Of course, I tweaked it to up the garlic and onion to double. I'm a garlic/onion lover, and sometimes I substitute out those for the fresh version instead.  I added 1 tsp of cornstarch (or 2 tsp of flour will work) to the mix which allows the spices to cling more readily to the meat as a thickened sauce. The spice mixture is great, but sometime was missing.  I looked around at a few other recipes and found one mentioning a beef bullion cube.  I have Better than Bullion paste (beef or chicken) and add a tsp while cooking the beef.  What a difference! It really gives  the meaty flavor that was lacking (hard to believe more meatiness is needed in a pound of ground beef, but it's true).  Whichever recipe you use, try adding some meat stock paste or equivalent (but do consider the added salt from bullion if you like it not too salty).  Also this recipe doesn't mention it, but adding a 1/4 to 1/2 cup of water towards the end after browning the meat with the seasoning allows the flavor to really mingle and absorb as you heat and reduce the sauce down a bit (that's where the cornstatch cling really shines). The water addition is just the basic instruction from the old packets I used to buy and it's not a step I'd ever skip.

This is excellent. It definitely tastes like the packet I usually used (will use this from now on). We mixed 1 lb. of browned-and-drained ground beef, this seasoning mix, plus a mixture of 2 tsp. of cornstarch and 2/3 cup of cold water. Then, we left it on low until all of it was warm.

This recipe was a life-saver!! After already mixing ingrediants for "seven layer taco dip," I realized that I was out of taco seasoning. Frantic, I ran to the computer and found this! YEAH!! I mixed it in with some cream cheese and sour cream to taste it first and it was great.  Worked even better in the dip!! If I'd had known how easy this was, I would have been making my own taco seasoning for a while now!! The only thing I changed was reduced the chili powder to 1/2 TBLS.  Very good and will make again!! Thanks Bill for posting this!

text:
Very quick.  No reason to buy pre-packaged Taco Seasoning.  I followed recipe except slightly decreased amt of red pepper flakes and omitted onion powder (didn't have any).  I cooked 1 & 1/4 lb. low fat ground beef with fresh garlic; poured off fat.  Added Taco seasoning + 1/2 c. fresh, chopped onions + 1 cup water. Brought to boil and simmered for about 15 min.  Next time I would decrease water to 2/3 or 3/4 cup (I had a little too much liquid, but not a problem).  Very good.  DH loved these tacos!

text:
This is absolutely delicious!! Thank you for sharing this recipe. I will NEVER go back to buying pre-packaged taco seasoning!! I love that I can make this recipe organically and especially love the fact that it is MSG FREE!! 

I found that if you add approximately 2/3 cup water to 3 tablespoons seasoning per pound of meat it makes the best flavor. I also prefer to add 1 Tablespoon flour to the recipe as this allows the seasoning to "stick" to the meat.

None
text:
I made super yummy enchiladas from this. Use this full recipe plus a can of tomato sauce and 2 cans of diced tomatoes w/green chilis (like Rotels) and throw it in a crock pot w/a few chicken breasts. After the chicken is cooked, shred it up and add about a third of the sauce to the chicken. Roll into flour tortillas with a bit of cheese (I used sharp cheddar). Put a little sauce in the bottom of a pan, place the enchiladas in the pan, cover with the rest of the sauce, then top with cheese and bake. So good.

text:
We've been using this recipe for a few months now and we love it.  I use it in meat for tacos, nachos and in tortilla soup recipes.  In my opinion the recipe is right for 1 pound of meat.  I make this up 4 oz at a time (4x the recipe) and keep it on hand. I was out of paprika for a while and it was great even without it.  Thanks for sharing.  **edit 2.25.11 I am still making the all the time... except for now I adjust the recipe for 80 servings (yes, 1/2 cup chili powder at a time!) and it lasts great in the plastic storage container.

None
text:
If comparing this to packaged, commercial seasoning mix this is very similar and very good. Submitter has the blend and balance of flavors spot on! Easy enough to adjust to personal tastes and I would highly recommend starting with a minimum amount of red pepper flakes and black pepper.  You can always add more, but you can't take it out, so better safe than sorry. For us that meant eliminating the red pepper flakes altogether and cutting back on the black pepper by half.  I did not find it necessary to add any flour or cornstarch as some others did, but I did add some water to moisten the meat and make it nice and juicy.  I found one recipe was the perfect amount for a pound of ground beef.

text:
My friend from NM swears this is the best! I make 8x the recipe, store it in a Ziploc bag in the freezer, & scoop out 3 T. per 1 lb. ground beef (plus 2/3 c. water). I make the following changes: cut cumin to 1/2 tsp., cut salt to 1/4 tsp., cut black pepper to 1/8 tsp., add 1 tsp. brown sugar, and substitute a pinch of cayenne pepper for the 1/4 tsp. crushed red pepper. No preservatives...WONDERFUL taste!!!

Really good recipe. I use less salt since I'm on a low sodium diet. I also add a little trick I learned when I lived in Mexico. Just a tiny pinch of unsweetened cocoa powder. You can't taste it but it really adds something. iI double the garlic and onion powder and don't use the crushed red pepper since my son doesn't like it spicy. I also add a little cornstarch so the sauce gets a little thick.

text:
I have seen this so many times on the recipe buzz and can't believe it has taken me so long to try it! I followed the top reviewer of the recipe and added the 1/2 Tblsp. of flour and 2/3 cup of water along with the seasoning. Those instructions worked out perfect. That same reviewer suggested 3 Tblsp of seasoning to 1 lb of ground beef. I measured out the recipe and it was basically 3 Tblsp so I used it all for one recipe. I would have been lost without the first reviewer. The flour and water are a must. I will never buy the packet seasoning again. It did have a slight hot kick to it. I think from the red pepper flakes, I am not sure. I did use a scant measurement of them and will probably reduce them even further next time. Other than that I believe this is a near clone of the packets but even better.

text:
Everyone in my family loves this flavor. First time I made it, I didn't have onion powder. It was pretty good without it. Then I made it the second time I had every ingredient in hand. It was perfect and learned the onion power had to be in there. If you follow the recipe as it's written, I don't think it's as much as 3 TBS combined, but it's enough to season 1 lb ground beef + 1/4 onions and 1/2 red/green peppers (all chopped). I'd add at least 1 cup water to cook.  It's a keeper.

text:
I would give this six stars if I could.  I will never use a store bought taco seasoning again.  It's easy to adjust the heat by adding or subtracting the red pepper.  I make a big batch and store it in a tightly covered jar.  One pound ground beef browned mixed with 3 tablespoons of the seasoning and 2/3 cup water- simmer for 10 minutes- makes perfect tacos/nachos.  I've also added it to my chili with excellent results.

text:
I did not care for this recipe of taco seasoning at all. I would have decreased the cumin which was extremely overwhelming and possibly the chilli powder also. I would have used more garlic and onion powder. (Salts plus sea salt were too salty.) Authentic Mexican flavoring is not like this at all. I love hot and spicy but the red pepper flakes and black salt were overpowering. More like the seasoning of chilli con carne. I will use my own recipe the next time or packaged rather than this recipe again.

text:
I stumbled across this recipe and I'm glad I did!  I now double it and store it in a spice container so it's ready to go.  I make the recipe as is, except I leave out the red pepper flakes (so the kids will eat it) and decrease the salt (with all the flavor it's not missed).  I use about 1 1/2 tablespoons of taco seasoning mix per pound of ground meat (turkey/beef) and add in a tsp of corn starch.  I stir both into 1/2 cup of water and then add to the browned meat and simmer for a couple minutes.  Simple, easy and tasty tacos!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe may save your -- and your family's -- brains. Make a bunch of it!  Store-bought taco seasoning typically has more than one excitotoxin within to add 'taste' when it's added to ground beef.  Excitotoxins like MSG, disodium inosinate (and several others) burn out neurons by exciting them overmuch. They over-fire, then they die . . . leaving holes where they used to be.  Tons of this garbage is worked into processed food to give it taste -- even baby food. Google 'excitotoxins', do some research, and protect your family by using recipes like this one instead of buying something off the shelf.

text:
Yummy! I love how you can control the salt, etc. in making your own. I cut the salt back to 1/4 tsp. And up the Paprika to 1 TB., and up the Oregano to 1/2 tsp. Better than ANY mix or taco seasoning envelope I've ever had! 2 TB. of this mix per lb. of ground meat works great! You too will want to triple this recipe, or even make enough to fill a jar for later use ;) That's what I do. You save a ton of money as opposed to those envelopes & it tastes better, no MSG and no corn flour or starches! Amazing recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After making it the first time, I made the following changes and it's perfect for us...spicy but not painful to the tongue.:
1/4 tsp salt; 1/4 tsp black pepper; pinch of red pepper flakes.  Per other recommendations, I also added 1/2 Tbs flour to this mixture. 

After browning the ground beef and draining it, put it back in the pan with 3.5 Tbs of seasoning (that's about how much this recipe makes) and 2/3 cup of water.  Stir it well, bring to a simmer and then simmer for 10-15 minutes.  If you don't simmer it for 10-15 minutes, the spices will taste raw and harsh.  They really mellow out during the simmer.

Display Name:
Renee “Nay” B

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6839523.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We only make this now.... Never store bought. I love that I can control the spice, salt & everything else. Being able to buy the spices from our local natural food store & blend it all myself makes me happy that we are getting fresh every time. I use my empty spice containers from the spices I use, so no wierd tastes. We make anywhere from 5x - 10x a recipe & store in the glass containers with plastic wrap over the opening before putting the lid on. We use double when cooking per lb of meat, since we love the flavor... I only add about 1/4C water per lb of meat. 
This is nothing like anything we've had from the store... It is way better. I hate that those ones in the store have a thickening agent. I like how the seasoning goes into the meat, instead of coating it in a goofy nasty mess like those seasoning packets do. Reading other reviews, I am inspired to use this when making 6 layer dip (in the sour cream) since I only use this in ground meat.... Turkey, beef, & bison.
What I did to tweak this is added only 1/2 the amount of salt, added more cumin, & used the 'regular' chili powder. I measured scant as well, nothing heaping. I also added to my mini food processor & blended it all to a powder... Mixes it very well while grinding up the red pepper flakes & oregano. I can't believe some people thought it was too spicy & some thought it was bland! My 4yo & 6yo love it. They aren't your typical kids eating junk food. I suggest try it again; but tweak it!

text:
Very good recipe as it is.   I added 1 Tbsp of flour to it to make it thicken a little and to add a little bulk to the recipe to make it easier to measure.   The way I use it, the meat has a meaty flavor and isn't completed masked, as the packets do.   However, there is still a distinct taco taste, which is perfect.   Compared to the packets, this is under 200 mgs of salt per serving, whereas the packets are about 600 mgs per serving.   I tried the recipe 1st with no salt and that was very blah.   I then stuck with the recipe on the 2nd attempt, but I think I could halve the salt and it would still be good.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  Since I don't like my taco too strong, I think I'll try to add about 2 T per pound of meat.  3 T was a bit to strong for me personally, though my husband loved it.  Otherwise for less heat, cut back on the crushed pepper.  Of course, add some water to simmer the meat and cornstarch or flour can thicken it if it is too runny.  2-3T recipe = 1 prepackaged spice.

text:
I originally made this to go in the "Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup" here, and it's excellent for that.  Then I tried it for taco meat, and I haven't bought a packet of taco seasoning since!  As another reviewer mentioned I stir 2 tsp. corn starch into a batch, and add 2/3 cup water to 1 lb. browned ground beef.  Bring to a boil, then simmer for a few minutes.  Perfect!  (I use 1/8 tsp. cayenne pepper in place of the 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes.)

city:

country:

text:
This is an excellent recipe partly because it includes the oregano and many of the other recipes on the site don't. Like many others I tweak it. Well, actually I just use it as an "outline" and make the following changes every time I make it. (I actually don't make a taco seasoning per se, but tacos from scratch every time. This is about what you need for 1.5 to 2 pounds of ground beef.) First I omit the paprika and black pepper. I don't use "chili powder" and substitute 1.5 TBSP New Mexico chili powder and slightly increase the other spices. ("Chili powder" is powdered dry chilis mixed with a lot of these other ingredients that are in the recipe, while "New Mexico Chili Powder" is pure powdered "warm" chilis.) I use cayenne in varying amounts rather than pepper flakes because I can control the heat better with it and I like the flavor of cayenne a lot better than black pepper (I want Mexican, not cajun.) I use 1 tsp fresh garlic (the crushed stuff in a jar) and 1/4 cup of chopped onion (prechopped and frozen) not granulated. Just after draining the majority of the grease I add the onions and garlic in and saute for a few minutes until the onions are thawed and beginning to cook. Then I make a clear spot in the middle of the pan and add my spices, sauteing them in the little bit of hamburger fat for a minute or two at medium then add a TBSP of tomato paste for a couple of minutes and letting it mellow over the heat before I add the water. When I add the water I add a tsp or s

country:
None
text:
Great replacement for the store brands!  

The big name taco seasonings weigh in at 1oz per packet which seasons 1 pound of meat.  This recipe tips the scale at just 1/2oz and seasons the same amount of meat as the store package.  Why?  Read the label of the packaged brands...  You're getting another 1/2oz of maltodextrin, corn flour, MSG, corn starch, preservatives and anticaking agents.  Mmmmm.  No thanks!  

Admittedly, I did add a scant 1/4 teaspoon of cornstarch to my finished seasoning to tighten up the finished meat sauce.  :)

I make quadruple batches of the seasoning (stored airtight) and use 1 tablespoon + 2 teaspoons per 1 pound of meat.

text:
I'm not buying those packets of taco seasoning at the store anymore, now that I've found this recipe!  It's easy and tastes great.  The directions of this recipe are kind of vague, so here's what I did.  First, I only used 1/8 tsp. red pepper flakes and only 1/2 tsp. each of salt and pepper.  This was just right for us.  I used one recipe for 1 lb. beef.  I browned the beef and drained it, added 3/4 cup water and stirred 1/2 Tbsp. corn starch into the seasoning, then added it to the beef.  Simmer for a few minutes and you have delicious taco meat!

I doubled the recipe and used two rounded soup spoons (which was probably 2 Tbl)with 1 lb hamburger - it was seasoned perfectly. Will definitly make this again, and will make it in bulk next time.

10.8.11  I see a couple one-star reviews posted recently.  This taco seasoning not only met my expectations, it exceeded them.  I just used it in Beef and Bean Crescent Burritos (AR site), and it provided lots of flavor with just the right amount of spiciness.  All I can say is it certainly worked for me! city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My wife & I are trying to not inadvertently consume MSG anymore so we made this as directed, but left the salt out until the end and added 2 teaspoons of corn starch and 2/3 cups of water, as typically directed on the seasoning packet.  This worked famously for ~1.5 lbs of ground chuck.  We tasted it without ANY salt added and you could definitely tell there was just *something* missing, so I eyeballed some kosher salt in the palm of my hand and sprinkled it into the finished product while it was still on the stove and stirred it around really good, then tasted it and it was absolutely perfect.  I will be a TAD lighter on the cumin next time, but that's just a personal preference, not a complaint.  This tasted great.  I will NEVER EVER buy a taco seasoning packet again!

text:
Delicious mix!  The only reason I'm giving it four stars instead of five is because the recipe didn't give a ratio of spice mix to meat.  I tried to approximate the amount of mix to the amount in a store bought packet, and the finished taco meat was so spicy it made my 10 year-old cry...but he ate every drop!  After reading some of the other reviews (like I should have before using it the first time...silly me), I'll try 2 tbsp to one pound of ground beef next time.

text:
Just a note to those looking for the store-bought effect, when adding to 1 lb ground beef for tacos, remember to add 2 tbs flour to the dry mix and 1/4 cup water to cook.  This thickens it up a bit, which is what most folks are used to when using the pre-packaged mix.  This is a really good spice recipe!

text:
I love the flavor of this recipe. This is SPICY. So if you are looking for a kid friendly seasoning, decrease the red pepper and chili powder. I make a quadruple recipe and store it so it is ready when I want it. I use 2-3 Tbs. per pound of meat and about the same or a little more water.

text:
Nom-nom! I love this combination of spices for tacos so much, I only add one more thing to make it mine; 1/2 of a freshly dried bay leaf that I've run through the spice grinder. 
Also, when adding the spice mix to the cooked ground meat, I include 1/4 cup water mixed with 1/4 cup tomato sauce for moisture, and then reduce at a simmer for a few minutes before serving.

I made a big batch of this a few months ago. We have really enjoyed it and have been perfecting the measurments to my families liking. We love this and will not go back to buying expensive taco packets. We use to only use Old Elpaso and now this is our go to! THANKS SO MUCH for the wonderful recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good base recipe and you can make the following small changes and this recipe will be very good:  Decrease the salt and pepper to 1/4 teaspoon each, decrease the cumin to 1 teaspoon, and here are the kickers...add 1 beef bullion cube and 1 teaspoon of flour.  The bullion cube will add the depth of flavor that is lacking, and the small amount of flour will thicken the final mix.  Just use a pound of browned ground beef and about 2/3 cup of water and let simmer until the liquid is absorbed and it will be a much better seasoning.

Tony Lucarelli

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This taco seasoning is the best! We don't even buy any store brand anymore (La Preferida was our preferred before this).

One thing to note: I use the entire recipe for 1.25 lbs. ground beef. After browning the beef, I drain it, wipe the pan out and then add the beef back to the hot pan. I then add the seasoning and a cup of water, bring it to a simmer and let it simmer for 15-20 minutes.

Also, because I like it saucier, I add a thickener. I looked at the store brands and most include corn masa, which is a thickener. You can pick up a couple pound bag of corn masa for about a buck and a half, and it will last you for hundreds of recipes - or you can try your hand at making tortillas! What I do is measure out all the other ingredients using a digital scale and then add enough masa to bring the total weight up to 1.25 ounces - which is the weight listed on most of the store bought taco seasoning blends.

text:
Really yummy! I did add a bit of water (1/3 c) after browning and seasoning the meat. Also, I've never added cornstarch or flour to my taco meat and think it's weird to "thicken" taco meat like that. Not sure - I'm in San Antonio and I'm not sure most places here thicken their meat. I've had plenty of "juicy" tacos. :) So, I won't follow those rec's. I did, however, let the meat simmer for 10 or so mins after adding the water (enough time to chop up avocado, lettuce, and tomato). I also think the recipe as written is a little on the spicy and salty side - I can handle the spicy, but my toddler can't, so next time I'm making this, I'm going to leave out the red pepper flakes, reduce the chili powder to 1 1/2 tsp, the black pepper to 1/4 tsp and the salt to 1/2 tsp.

Display Name:
Josh

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe uses basic spices that everyone has in their house, and it tastes great, so if you find one better I'd like to see it!  Other reviewers complained about the salt, but if anything, I think it could easily have taken a little more.  I replaced the 1/4 t of crushed red pepper with cayenne, but I barely noticed any heat.  Many reviewers added flour or cornstarch to thicken, and have the sauce "stick to the meat."  I intentionally did not do this, because that's how store-bought seasoning packets come out.  I did not want my meat gooey or thick like a sloppy joe.  I prefer my taco meat to come out crumbly and a little dry, just like how I see it at most mexican restaurants I've been to.  I also didn't want the spice to overpower the taste of the meat, and this recipe achieves that goal.  The next time I try this, I will follow the advice of some reviewers and add some beef base to the meat.  I've come to find that "Better Than Bouillon" is a great product, and worth the extra money for great flavor.  I'll never use bouillon cubes again.  Everyone should have Better Than Bouillon chicken and beef in their fridge!

I left out the red pepper flakes, black pepper, and salt. (Cooking for young kids! And since we were using the whole recipe, the chili powder was spicy  enough.) I left out the oregano too, but I'll try it in there next time. I added the whole spice mixture to 1 lb. of browned ground beef, then added 1/2 can of diced tomatoes (which contained salt, so finished product was plenty salty), and about 1 tsp. of flour to thicken (mixed into the juice from the tomatoes). The result was spectacular. Everyone loved it! Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I was a bit skeptical only because I've unfortunately become accustomed to the salty, store-bought taco seasoning.  But boy am I glad I decided to try this!  It was very good!  I read some reviews and followed these suggestions;  omitted the black pepper, used 1/8 tsp. cayenne pepper in place of crushed red pepper, added 1 tsp. corn starch, and added 1/2 tsp. of beef bouillon paste during the simmering process. I used 3/4 to 1 cup water and it was too much.  Next time, I will use 2/3 cup.  It's a wonderful taco seasoning without all of the unnecesssary salt!

text:
This is very good - but I'd make a few changes next time I make it.  I would used dried, minced onion instead of the onion powder, double the cumin and substitute a pinch of cayenne for the pepper flakes.  Also, I like how the packaged kind thickens up a bit, so I added a tsp or so of cornstarch to the mixture.  I LOVE that it is all natural and NO MSG!!!

text:
I don't review recipes very often because they really have to impress me. For years I've tried taco seasoning recipes, making my own, using a store bought packet and just throwing seasonings in to fit my taste. I prefer the restaurants that use a taco meat without a heavy "taco" flavor and do NOT like the ones with ketchup or taco sauce added to them. I'm very much a purist so less to me is better. So I tried this one expecting it to taste like a taco seasoning packet. I made the whole recipe and cooked 2 lbs. of hamburger meat and added the seasoning to taste along with some water to help mix. I kept tasting it as it was cooking and kept adding the seasoning and almost used the whole recipe. Husband and daughter (11 yrs.) loved it as a meat burrito, I had a crunchy taco and almost 14 yr. old son doesn't really like tacos so he added ketchup and made a sloppy joe and he loved it. I liked it too. It didn't have an overwhelming taco flavor. All the spices worked really well together and seemed to have a perfect balance so not any one spice was overpowering. Thanks for the recipe! I should use this from now on.

WHOO DOGGIE!  Careful of the strength of the chili powder.  I used med-hot from the Mexican food section.  MUST CUT DOWN NEXT TIME!  Otherwise great - used 1lb ground beef, 2 TBSP seasoning, 1/2-3/4 cup water and simmered 20min.  Update: OK so chili powder is a mixture of seasonings including red chili.  The mexican red chili powder I used is NOT a mix thus the heat factor.  We actually like the heat of using 1/2 of each for this.  Used up my last packet of taco seasoning left in the pantry and my husband commented on the lack of taste it had.  Won't go back to the packet!

text:
Ok, so yes this became the official taco seasoning recipe in my house. NO MORE TACO SEASONING PACKS AFTER THIS RECIPE FOR ME!!! 

I use the entire mix for 1pound of ground beef simply because I enjoy a lot of flavor. I personally add double the cayenne pepper because I love spicy. I then add 2/3 cup of water, bring to a boil, then turn down to low-medium heat to simmer for 10 minutes. Yumm I promise!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great alternative to the packets of taco mix you buy at the store. It is my go-to recipe! I'm especially fond of it because you can control how spicy or salty you want to make it. My husband loves spicy food so I add a little extra pepper flakes and I use Penzey's "Black & Red" seasoning, which is black pepper and cayenne pepper mixed together, in place of the black pepper. I don't add any salt to this recipe and I honestly don't miss it! I usually triple this recipe to season 3lbs of ground turkey at a time and typically let the meat simmer in the seasoning with 1 1/2 to 2 cups water to allow the meat to absorb the seasonings. Delicious!

text:
Love love love!  I'm doing my best to avoid processed foods and foods with additional preservatives so I thought I've give this a whirl.  I've made this a few times and my only recommendation would be to make MORE so you can have some on hand to throw into other recipes in the future!  I've used it in tacos of course, but I've also mixed it in sour cream for a quick dip for quesadillas, put a pinch in ranch for a Mexican dressing to go with a salad... the possibilities are endless now that I'm not tied to the old seasoning packet.  Thank you Bill!!

text:
Yumm! I didn't have any oregano (weird, huh!) or onion powder. I only had onion salt so I used that in the amount stated for onion powder and decreased the salt amount by 3 teaspoons (I had quadroopled the recipe). I then added diced onions to the ground beef. Solved the onion powder problem! I cooked up 4 pounds of ground beef and added a tablespoon of white whole wheat flour then the taco seasoning with about 3/4 cup or so of water. I did decrease the crushed pepper to suit kid tastes but it was delicious!  I popped the leftover seasoned beef into the freezer until the next taco night! 2 meals -one time cooking!

text:
This is perfect taco seasoning. I flipped over the store brand and a well known brand of taco seasoning packets and the ingredients are not great. There's a lot of salt and MSG in them. I decided I could find a better recipe online and this one was perfect! I already had everything at home. It was just a matter of knowing how much of each spice to use. I used it on ground turkey which has little flavor to begin with. After adding the seasoning you wouldn't know it's not beef. Thanks for the recipe!

country:
None
text:
This is another great recipe for the books! Taco night was everyone's favorite when I make this. It makes you want to never eat another Taco Bell anything ever again. I've actually never had a taco this good from anywhere. I always add a little more everything especially crushed red pepper for the spice. I took the advice from someone else and added flour to the mix before shaking mixing the spice mixture together. I always dust the meat lightly with the spice mix while browning and then after it's done while it's simmering with the water. While doing that I prepare my cheese sauce mix which is velveta and ro-tel hot diced tomatoes (make sure they're hot or else it won't be the same) and warm them up together. This is the icing on the cake for the tacos. I then prepare whatever else I want for the tacos and put them in separate dishes with spoons so everyone can fix what they want. It's amazing.

text:
I did halve the salt to add 1 beef bouillon as another reviewer suggested and it is muy perfecto!!! We will never buy the packet again!!!
Update: I boiled the meat to get that resturant texture. I did not drain the water; I added the whole bowl (3T) of seasoning to the beef in the water and let it reduce. I then added 1/4 tsp of cornstarch to cold water in a bowl and added it to the meat... BEST EVER!!!

text:
We no longer buy packaged taco seasoning - this is excellent and made with ingredients I always have on hand. I use 1 batch of this recipe as written (subbing 1/8 tsp. of cayenne for the 1/4 tsp. of crushed red pepper flakes) and stir in 1 TBSP of flour (I use whole wheat, works great). Add that mixture to 1 lb. browned/drained ground beef with 3/4 cup water and simmer for 10 minutes. Perfect!

This is better than any of those packets of Taco Seasoning at the store. I pulled out the seasoning packet that came with the taco shells and secretly used this recipe in its place. Everyone wanted to know what I did different. 
I used the entire recipe with 1 1/2 pounds lean ground beef.  After browning the meat, I added the spice mix and browned it slightly. Then added 3/4 Cup Water and 1-2 Tablespoons of flour. Turned out perfect. I'm not sure if this saves you any money but who cares! This is a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great tasting recipe! I have yet to use it on plain meat, like ground beef -- I've only used it in recipes so far. However, the flavor is more robust than packet seasoning and I love that I can tweak it to my liking, and don't have to worry about running out so often. If you double this recipe, the weight comes out to 1.25oz, which I believe is the weight of a seasoning packet... but I used ALL of the doubled batch in my most recent recipe and the flavor is VERY strong. A little too strong for my liking, and taco seasoning is probably one of my favorite flavors ever. I'd recommend making a double batch but not using it all immediately, and adding more to taste. I'd recommend cutting down the salt or removing it altogether if you're not a big salt fan -- there's a fair amount of sodium in this already.

text:
i took a look at the comments first, and decided that the recipe (yielding ~ 2.5 TB) was perfect for 1lb of ground beef. it was INCREDIBLY spicy. My BF and I love our food spicy, and we used the meat for chile rellenos...he was literally sweating as we ate. So if you're going to use this, keep in mind the hotness and I suggest starting with less, then adding more if you so desire. The 2-3 TB per LB suggestions may not work for everyone.

text:
It really was just like the mccormick taco seasoning packet.  I subbed chipotle powder for the redpepper flakes, and omitted the onion powder (dont have any.) I added sauteed onion to compensate.  Used 2 tbsp for 1lb of ground beef, with 1tbsp of flour and about 3/4 to 1 cup of water.  I cooked it all together for about five minutes then it sat for about 3 minutes in the pan off the heat.  the liquid evaporated and thickened perfectly.

Don't know if I'll ever buy taco seasoning again!

text:
I was born in Texas and have lived here for 35 years and I know my Tex-Mex cooking.  This is the BEST taco seasoning I have EVER tasted!!!  I make tacos at least twice a month (we love tacos) for my husband & boys (preschool aged) so I have had plenty of opportunities to try lots of different seasonings.  This is by far the BEST.  The flavors are all perfectly balanced!  Since I was feeding this to small children, I left out the red pepper flakes, but there was still plenty of "warmth" in the seasoning.  Not too bland for grownups.  I tripled the recipe for about 2.5 lbs of meat and even more  veggies (1 cup chopped onion, 1 cup chopped bell pepper and two 14.5 oz cans diced tomatoes, undrained).  The liquid from the canned tomatoes really helped bind everything together.  I also added an extra teaspoon of cumin b/c we just like it that way.  Thank you for this recipe!!!

I quadrupled the recipe to have enough left over to save for another time...took the advice of others who said it was possibly 'too salty' and reduced the sea salt by 1 teaspoon  and did not put black pepper in it (in case it was too hot from the red pepper flakes), adding a couple of dashes at the end...IT WAS PERFECT!  I am definitely shouting that out so all can hear (see)...Fabulous recipe and done in less than a minute if you have all your spices organized in the cabinet :) The meal has been eaten and now the balance has been stored in a jar in the cabinet.  Thanks for something as simple and delicious as this...did not add flour to the meat as someone suggested...no extra gluten was needed.

Have always used taco seasoning packets from the store, I never even thought about making my own. text:
I just made this (minus the red peper flakes as it was for kids) for my daughter's grade 6 class as one of the children has severe allergies making packaged mixes a little tricky. 8 lbs of ground beef for 19 kids and only about 3 tbsp of meat left at the end; I'd say it was a success. I converted the recipe to 120 servings. I ended up using about 1/3 of the mix for the 8 lbs of meat. I advise adding a little at a time and tasting until you get the spice level you want. I've kept the remainder in a sealed jar and will use it the next time we have tacos at home. Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I make 60 servings as that is what my jar holds:
6 tbsps chili powder
1 tbsp garlic powder
1 tbsp onion powder
1 1/2 tsps oregano
1 tbsp paprika
3 tbsps cumin
1/2 tsp each red pepper flakes, cayenne pepper and black pepper
I add salt or more pepper if needed depending on what I am making as I use this as my general Mexican style seasoning

Since finding this recipe on AR, I have not (and will not) buy any sort of taco seasoning packet...the flavors of this seasoning mix are amazing!  I think the hotness is just right, but the kids claim its a bit spicy.  My suggestion, if you have young children or picky eaters, is to hold off on mixing in the hot spices until last.  Then add it little by little to taste at the end.

userID:
6699948
Display Name:
MirDeNoms
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the better recipes I've tried although a little tweaking makes it perfect. I played around with a few small batches and kept getting the feeling it was missing something. Where it calls for 1 tbls of chili powder, use 1/2 tbls regular chili powder and 1/2 tbls hot Mexican chili powder. Where it calls for 1/2 tsp paprika, use 1/4 tsp paprika and 1/4 tsp "smoked" paprika (makes a big difference). One other important addition is a 1/4 to 1/2 tsp of ground coriander. I also "heaped" the garlic and onion ingredients and omitted the red pepper flakes (I like to add them while cooking). The coriander and smoked paprika made a huge diference. I also used 1/2 of the oregano and crushed it to near powder. Hope this helps. Enjoy.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This Taco Seasoning was excellent.  I used it with some organic ground beef.  We used the beef in soft multi-grain tortillas.  I served the tacos with some Mexican rice & black beans.  My boyfriend raved that it was the most satisfying meal that he had in awhile.  (I guess this is good & bad!)  I will definitely be making this again.  A little tip for those in western Washington - if you go to PCC, you can get organic spices (they have a section where you can measure out how much you want to use).  This was such an awesome option as opposed to buying a bottle of spices that you rarely use!

I mixed some up last night.  I'm always looking for a way to cut cost.  This Taco Seasoning mix will help with this. I used about a heaping tablespoon of flour and about two tablespoons of the mix and added about 1/2 cup of water.  Of course you can change the amounts to suit your taste.  I also didn't have any crushed red pepper flakes, so I use about an 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper, some of my family members don't care for really spicy food, so I have to keep things milder for them.  I know I will keep this mixed up in our spice cabinet and not buy packets again!  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
Made this seasoning last night to use for chicken tacos.  Excellent flavor.  It will be my go-to seasoning from now on.  I did not have onion powder so I used an equal amount of dried minced onion.  Didn't have sea salt either so I used 1-1/4 tsp. of regular table salt.  For 2 large cut up chicken breasts, I used 2-1/2 tbsp. of the seasoning and 1/2 cup water. I will use a little less than that next time with 1/4 cup of water.  Worth doubling or tripling to keep in a jar in the cabinet.

text:
Oh my goodness...this was amazing!!  I used the whole recipe on 3 large, diced chicken breasts for tacos and it was so good!!  I made a few changes from lack of ingredients, but not many.  I did not have sea salt, so I subbed table salt only cut the amount in half.  I also omitted the pepper because I just didn't feel like putting it in for some reason and I didn't miss it at all.  I also was out of red pepper flakes, so I subbed 1/8 tsp cayenne and the spice was perfect.  Buying taco seasoning seems really pointless when there is an amazing recipe for it you can throw together in a few minutes that doesn't contain chemicals or an overwhelming amount of salt.  Thanks so much for the post.  Will use for the rest of my life :)

text:
Excellent recipe! I just make a large batch of this and then keep it on hand to make tacos anytime. Also, I stir in just a bit of potato starch (I'm allergic to cornstarch) to the batch. When cooking, I add a bit of water to the seasoned meat and combines with the starch to create an excellent saucy taco meat just like the packaged stuff! I love it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So much better than store bought. I loved it so did my family. I added three tbs spoons to each pound of beef. And added water in stages just so I could get the right moisture. I made 5 pounds of tacos with this recipe. I also used this recipe with chicken burritos. It was so yummy also. I just took pound of left over boneless chicken breast and cooked it in 2 cans of chicken broth and about 2 cans of water tsp spoon of a garlic powder and 1/4 tsp ground pepper. Once the chicken started boiling I turned it low and let it simmer for about 1/2 an hour more or less. Once it was done and tender I shredded it with two forks. Tossed the chicken in a skillet with a little water and 3 tbs of the seasoning and cooked as I did the beef it was so good and moist.  I plan to make a huge batch of this and freeze it. It will be used up in now time.  Thanks for sharing. Vera

This seasoning blend is amazing. I 
will never go back to packaged taco
seasoning again. I used to make my

triple to have a reserve.

text:
I originally tried this recipe for two reasons.  #1, the Old El Paso seasoning at the store grows dull very quick when a 5 and 6 year old demand tacos at least once a week.  #2, it's one of the only recipes I have seen on this site with so much posituve reviews.  Well over 500!  That's incredible.  

  I did alter it a bit, as most of you did.  First thing I did, being that the little guys were eating it, I completely cut out the red pepper and only used half the seasalt.  Just to a mild version for them.  I also added half a cup of fresh chopped onion to the meat while it was browning and it turned out great!  

  In the future, I will create two mason jars of this seasoning to use on Taco Night, one Mild and One Extra Extra Spicy for good ole' dad!  

  As a father who cooks for the family, I really needed to find something that would please everyone, knowing that I am no Iron Chef.  This recipe did the trick.  Thank you very much.

This was just the perfect mix of spices for my taco meat. I try to slow cook a lot to save time at the "witching hour" so I toss 1 lb of (browned) ground turkey, a 14 oz can diced tomatoes and 1 sliced onion in the crockpot, add this recipe of seasoning and you've got delish taco fillings waiting when you get home. text:
This is great! Of course I was missing the seasoning mix when I decided to make tacos last night. I put in a search for taco seasoning, never thinking anything would come up, and I found this. It's very easy to tweak to your taste. I halved the chili powder, used 1/4 t pepper, left out the pepper flakes, and used cilantro in place of the oregano. I added a little more than 1/2 c of water, and 1 t cornstarch to the mixture to thicken. It tastes just like the packaged kind, even better! As the recipe stands it would be much hotter than the packaged seasoning I'm used to using, so if you like hot, don't change a thing! Thank you, thank you! I'll never have to buy seasoning mix again.

text:
The flavor of this is great!  Like many others here, I didn't have a packet of taco seasoning when I needed it so checked here.  I'm so glad I did! I mixed all the seasonings together in a plastic bag, cutting the amount of chili powder and red pepper flakes in half, and using regular salt instead of sea salt.  I added the entire amount of seasoning to a pound of ground beef that had just been browned along with a 1/2 cup of water.  I mixed very well and allowed to cook on medium stiring occassionally for about 10 minutes. Next time though, I will completely omit the red pepper flakes.  Even using only 1/8 of a teaspoon has left my mouth on fire.

country:

text:
I  I think that, with that ingredient  halved, it's just right. That's a huge reduction in spice, so I'll knock off a whole star. 
I have to say, my major complaint is with the reviewers, once again. Someone said there shouldn't have been cayenne or red pepper. Uh, there's not. Someone else said it was too salty with the onion and garlic salt. No...powder, NOT salt. More people complaining about how, even if they cut the black pepper in half, it's too spicy...That's because the red pepper flakes and the chili powder are the heat, not black pepper! If you like the consistency of flour our cornstarch, add them, but don't knock a recipe for not already containing those when it's a SPICE recipe. 
Allrecipes, you really need a REPLY TO option on reviews so that reviewers can see why their recipe went wrong.

Way, way too much salt. To properly season a pound of meat, you need about 3 tablespoons of the seasoning, which results in an overly salty taco meat. Reduce the salt to 1/4 teaspoon and it may be ok. You can always add more later.

text:
This is so much better than any envelope I have tried. I will never buy them again.  I added a tablespoon of dehydrated onion and 1/4 tsp of cayenne pepper instead of pepper flakes but we like spicy in our house.     I browned a pound of extra lean ground chicken, added this recipe plus 2/3 c water and simmered until it boiled down. Then, I filled a green pepper half way with the mixture put a layer of 2% cheddar, filed the pepper with more seasoned chicken then topped with more cheese and baked until the peppers were browned.   My dieting wife loved it!!!

Love it with tweaks to make it more like Taco Bell mild:
1 tsp. chili powder
1/2 tsp. pepper
1/4 tsp. garlic powder
1/4 tsp. onion powder
1/4 tsp. dried oregano
1/2 tsp. paprika
1 1/2 tsp. ground cumin
1 tsp. salt

text:
My go-to 'Mexican' seasoning! I sub cayenne for the red pepper flakes (I never like biting into one of those, so the ground works just as well). If I'm making fajitas or pork I usually add an extra 1/2 TBS of cumin to knock up the flavor. Also use this in homemade black beans, refried beans, Mexican rice, and burrito filling. The taste is so much better than the packaged stuff--you're able to control the sodium and spice levels so everyone is happy.

Display Name:
Jenny1980

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had every ingredient for this- EXCEPT the crushed red pepper flakes which I am not a fan of! But I was SO happy! But even happier after making the tacos! This recipe is beyond excellent! I did not use salt- I think the chili powder has a "salty" taste on its own (there is no salt in it) ... so I omitted the salt here. Just as I do with home-made fajita seasoning- I do not include salt for health reasons. Here is a tip- for those whom enjoy spicier tacos  / latin meals---- use 3 or 4 drops of Tapatio hot sauce when the ground beef is done - just before you add this awesome seasoning. Maybe 3 for starters. Tapatio is NOT hot but just "warm" enough for a bit of a kick. I do not suggest american hot sauces for Latin food. BUT- back to this recipe....I measured everything just as listed and it was fantastic. I felt so good about making a seasoning on my own without the sodium that is contained in manufactured, " store-bought" seasonings. The cumin is the beauty here. And yes I did use black pepper. I simply had the stuff in my kitchen to make these tacos magic. I kid you not! Try and enjoy! Even if you have to go and buy these seasonings- you can find them at very low prices. Some less than a dollar! Its well worth it for your health and for the unique, fresh taste of something home-made- instead of a taco "kit" or a manufactured brand of seasoning---oh! ....wait....one tip,,,,add just 1/3 cup ?? of water and simmer until evaporated. GOOD LUCK! and ,,,,Peace and love- "Jenny"

I have been using this recipe for a few years and it's my goto recipe.  I do have store bought that doesn't have msg but I can't taste a big difference except that the store bought is saltier.  I like being able to control the salt and pepper.  I do use less pepper, red pepper flakes and regular salt. Lastly I just tried this recipe with cooked shredded chicken breast meat sauteed with onions and a can of chopped tomatoes, rolled the filling in tortillas and covered in salsa and cheese baked together - my husband and kids thought it was delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is our go-to recipe for taco seasoning. No more store-bought versions for me. I usually have all these ingredients on hand, so this is very easy to whip up -- and then use as little or as much as preferred. That being said, I always pretty much go by the recipe's guidelines. Well, tonight I realized I couldn't do that, as I lacked a couple of ingredients after I recently performed a huge purge of past-expiry spices (and hadn't had a chance to replace them). Unwilling to foray out to the grocery store in rush-hour traffic, I decided to substitute a Tablespoon of Cholula hot sauce for the chili powder (BTW, who in Texas runs out of chili powder, am I right?) and a heaping Tablespoon of instant (dried) chopped onions for the onion powder -- then, b/c of the wet ingredient (Cholula), I gave the mixture a good stir and let it sit for about 15 minutes to reconstitute the dried onions and let the other flavors meld. It all came out WONDERFUL. I was worried the vinegar in the hot sauce would overpower the other flavors -- but it was fine. Still, I'm going back to the original recipe ... that is, when I have the proper ingredients on hand. Two noms up.

Easily the best tacos I have ever tasted.  It is a fairly healthy recipe, no one ingredient has a lot of sodium.  I don't find it spicy, but my girlfriend does, so feel free to cut out the red pepper flakes. userID:

Display Name:
Douglas1131977

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ive found that using half as much ground red pepper as crushed is easier to use but the flavors are rather good. There are people that do not like it or do not think it has flavor or has too much flavor. This is because of the brand of chili powder used. I personally prefer the types that are a bit closer to red due to the flavor being less cuminy. If you use a weak chili powder it will be bland. if you use a darker chili powder it will be more cuminy. So pretty much all I am saying is to be sure to use a chili powder you like since 1/3 of this entire seasoning is made of chili powder. I also strongly recommend using ground red pepper since it more consistent in heat, just use 1/8 tsp instead of 1/4. I say this because my most recent crushed red pepper is way hotter than any other i have ever bought. And if I used it this would be inedible to most. Using ground red pepper and a redder chili powder my wife, who does not like things too spicy could eat it no problems as could my 3 year old son. I find it slightly spicier than store bought. But with a decent flavor that i had to mix 2 brands of store bought to get before. I've made this at least 6 times so far. A last note, please do not use 10 year old spices and complain that a spice mix has no flavor.

I forgot to get the packet of seasonings when I bought the ingredients for a taco dinner and decided to look up a recipe. I am so glad I found this recipe. I tried it out on my daughter without telling her it wasn't a packet mix. She couldn't tell the difference. I used soy crumbles because we don't eat meat...it was great! No more packet stuff for me. I decreased the red pepper flakes..we don't like it too spicy. I am going to make a big batch of this to keep on hand. Thanks!

text:
2/7/2013: SO much better than store bought...plus, you can control the heat, sodium and can be sure there is no MSG! I have made numerous recipes of this for myself and for gifts (I buy empty spice bottles at Penzy's Spices). I've used this most often in  Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup here on AR, and it's always a crowd pleaser. I use anywhere from 3 - 4 Tbsp. As a matter of fact, I borrowed a friends slow-cooker for a party and am returning it with a copy of that recipe and a jar of this seasoning. Thank you Bill Echols and everyone else here who takes the time to review these recipes. So much great input! ***UPDATE 9/8/2015 Still making this seasoning mix. I make it in big batches to give to family members with kids. I've re-supplied one niece a couple of times because she goes through it fairly quickly (4 kids). I use about 3 Tbsp per pound of meat. Good stuff.

text:
I never knew how easy it was to make this from scratch! I skipped the salt and the onion powder, and it still tasted great.  I have made it 2 nights in a row now, using LENTILS not ground beef.  Cooked up some green lentils, drained, added veggie oil and this seasoning.  Piled it into hard shell tacos with cheese and sour cream the first night, then with cheese on top of nachos the second night.  So delicious! I like this way better than the packaged stuff, which to me always seems to have a chemical/plastic taste.  Will try it with ground beef soon, but lentils are just so economical and healthy!

country:
None
text:
Like many others, I turned to this recipe when I was in the midst of making dinner and discovered I was out of taco seasoning packets.  This was so good.  I will never go back to the packets again.  

Made a few tweaks.  Loved it!
- Mixed with 1 tbsp corn starch
- Added 2/3 cup of water after I stirred it in the browned meat
- Used with 1 lb of ground turkey (delicious)!
- Didn't add any salt, based on feedback it was salty.  No problem with salt, unlike the packets.

Save yourself the $1 and try this recipe.  Couldn't be faster or easier.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly the first time. Too hot for one member of the family so the second time I cut the black pepper back by half and it was perfect for my picky eater. I now make up a large jar so I can just pull it out of the cabinet and use 2T worth per one pound hamburger. I add 1/2c water to the cooked hamburger and taco seasoning mix. When the water has cooked off I'm done. Easy and cheap. Great recipe!

country:

text:
I'm only giving this 4 stars because I had to fool around with different types of chilis to get the best flavour.  I use Dried Ancho Chilies that I get at a local Mexican grocery store.  Using them this recipe is fantastic!!!!  I also use about 1/8 tsp cayenne powder instead of the hot pepper flakes, just feel it mixes in better that way.  Love this recipe - thanks for posting!!!

text:
Thought there were some envelopes of taco spice mix in the pantry - I was wrong.  This will now be my go-to for taco/nacho meat!  Used kosher salt (salt is salt is salt - unles it's iodized), 1/4 tsp. cayenne instead of pepper flakes (better heat distribution).  Used the entire recipe in 2 pounds of 80/20 ground beef - and added 3/4 cups water, then simmered 10 minutes.  The nachos were great!

country:
None
text:
I ran out of my jar of taco seasoning, so used this in a pinch for vegetarian tacos - this recipe is yummy!  I'll never use a packet again!  

I left out the garlic and onion powder, and used about half an onion and 1/2tsp of crushed garlic from a jar when I actually made the tacos.  I also left out the red pepper flakes because my kids would think it too spicy.  I used 2 1/2Tbsp of the mix for tacos made with 12oz veggie protein crumbles instead of meat, and it was really tasty!  Cooked everything in about 1/4 cup of water to help meld spices.  Kids finished their whole dinner, so you know it's good :)

text:
My dear bf volunteered to make supper.  He thought we were out of the packaged seasoning, so he tried this recipe.  We have no paprika, so he subbed cayenne pepper!  It was delicious, though a little spicier than he likes.
Update:  I have made the recipe with no mods many times now.  It is great.  5 batches fit perfectly into an old spice jar from Aldi, so then all you need to know is to scoop out 8 tsps OR 2 Tbs + 2 tsps OR 2 heaping Tbs OR 3 scant Tbs per pound of meat

region:

country:
None
text:
Came out great.  Based on other reviews & what I had around, made the following tweaks:
Didn't have garlic powder, so used garlic granules, upped it to 1tsp.
Didn't have onion powder, so used dried minced onions, also upped it to 1tsp.
Left out the crushed red pepper flakes as I thought the chili powder would make it hot enough.
Added about 1 tsp corn starch.
I left everything else as is.

I then combined the whole thing with 1lb browned ground beef + 1 can diced tomatoes + 1 onion + 4 cloves garlic + 1tbsp tomato paste. Served over rice w/sour cream.  Yum!  Seasoning was pretty much perfect.  Can't wait to see if time in the fridge improves the leftovers!

Very good seasoning. This came in handy when I realized that i did not have packets of taco seasoning. I did not add as much red pepper flakes as I did not want it too spicy. Instead of dried oregano I used fresh oregano, chopped up. I did scale back on the amount of oregano. It smelled just like how a taco seasoning packet does only better. Very easy to put together as I had all the ingredients on hand. What's great about this recipe is that I have more control on the amount of seasonings and level of spiciness I put into the mixture. I ended up close to 3T worth of taco seasoning that I used for my recipe tonight. I used this taco seasoning for,"Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup," from this website.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have very limited experience cooking. However, this recipe was super easy to follow. In fact, the most difficult thing for me was going to the store for the spices and other taco makings I did not have, and even that was easy. 

The recipe does not note the amount of water to add to the browned and drained hamburger once you add the seasoning mix. After reading some reviews and completing a Google search, I added 3/4 of a cup of water, and that worked perfectly.

The flavor had a little kick to it, which I prefer. This is way better than any of the packets you buy in the store and it is so worth taking just a few minutes to mix some spices together. 

I bumped up the quantity from 10 to 80, which results in 18 tablespoons of mix. At 3 tablespoons of mix per pound of hamburger, this is enough for 6 pounds of hamburger. Instead of mixing spices each time I make tacos, I just placed all of the ingredients into a jar, shook the jar really well, and the mixture should maintain a strong flavor until I use up the rest of the seasoning.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any paprika or red pepper, so I substituted a total of 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne pepper instead.  I also used slightly less than a teaspoon of sea salt, and it was still plenty salty, so I think that could be reduced next time.  With my substitutions, it made slight over 6 teaspoons (or about 2.5 tablespoons).  I ended up using about 1.5 Tbs for 1/2 lb of ground beef and the amount of seasoning seemed to work just fine.  Like others mentioned I added flour to the mix before dumping on the browned, drained beef and added water (a little over 1/3 cup) and let it simmer down.

text:
Almost perfect!  The only change I make is to also add 1 tsp of corn starch for thickening, and helps "stick" to the beef.  After placing all the ingredients (including corn starch) into a 1c container with lid, I give it a shake.  Just 1-2Tbsp of this seasoning with a bit of water works great in ground beef.  I've also used this as a seasoning on chicken breast, onion & green bell pepper when making homemade fajitas.  Fantastic!

August 2015

2019... still using this recipe for my taco seasoning.  Everyone raves at how good the tacos are.  I'm sure because the spices are fresher and there are no fillers, binders, thickeners.  Great recipe!

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I make this recipe once a week and it works perfectly for taco's or burritos and even mexican rice!  I use 2 lbs of ground beef and follow the recipe as described and add a few more red chilli flakes because my family likes heat.  I add all the seasonings to the pan with the meat,  I then add 1 cup of water and let it simmer until reduced to desired dryness.    Very authentic and tastes even better the next day after letting all the flavors meld!

text:
This is easy and fun to make.  My husband keeps asking me whether I liked his taco seasoning better (so I give this 4 stars vs. 5), but then he remembered how much work his was!!  This is easy and fun!  To actually use it with beef, use 3 T for every 1 lb beef.  Add 2 tsp cornstarch (optional) to 2/3 cup or 3/4 cup water (necessary) and add to the beef.  Last time I forgot the water and it was dry!

text:
Perfect blend of seasonings.  I didn't have any onion powder so I left it out and just used about 1/8 cup finely chopped onion when I browned my beef for tacos. I added about a tsp. of cornstarch with the spices. When adding the spices to the browned beef I added about 1/3+ cup water and simmered the mixture for about 10 minutes.  I used this for 2 lbs of ground beef and it was just right.

text:
This is an excellent, easy, and cheap recipe for those taco nights. However, we did find it pretty spicy so next time we will be cutting the red pepper flakes in half since we're not really spicey folks.   Also, I did like others did and I added 1/2 tbsp of flour to 3 tbsps. of the taco seasoning mixture BEFORE putting into the pan with the ground beef. I also added 2/3 cup of water to the ground beef once I added in the taco seasoning/flour mixture.

text:
I think this recipe is great! I had to cook 20 pounds of taco meat for a birthday party and didn't want to spend the $ on season packets since I knew I had all the spices at home. Found this recipe and it worked well. I quadrupled the recipe per 5lbs. of meat and took out a bit of salt. When the meat was brown, I added 1 cup of water (for 5lbs. of meat) and the seasoning and let simmer for about 10 minutes. Food was being made for the next day, so it sat in the fridge overnight and blended all the seasoning just right. It tastes great and the heat factor is dead on. Thanks!

text:
I've been using this recipe for about a year now and I can't imagine going back to the packet seasoning.  This is so good!  After the meat is browned I add 2 T of flour and 2 T of seasoning, stir, then add about 3/4 C water, simmering slightly until thickened.  Last Christmas I bought cute little spice jars at The Container Store and gave this blend as gifts to my neighbors.

text:
This is really good but oh mama is it hot! I love spicy food but had to tone this waaaay down with some brown sugar and added more garlic salt, onion powder and oregano to cut back on the heat of the chili powder and red pepper. I added about 2 tablespoons of the mix to a pound of ground turkey and let it simmer with 1/2 cup water for 10-15 minutes.  Much easier and cost-efficient than the packaged stuff and I know exactly what's in it so will use this from now on but the recipe as written is definitely is not for kids or the faint-hearted!

text:
My husband and I use this recipe now any time we want tacos.  We only scale back a little on the salt since we feel it not only has plenty of seasoning (you won't miss it) but we try to cut down on our sodium intake.  We also add 2/3 cup of water when we add the seasoning to the meat.  Either way, this seasoning is great.  Less sodium and no msg and no artificial ingredients like you get in those store bought packets.  Best of all, you probably have all of these ingredients on hand already so no need to waste any money on buying the store bought variety!  This one is much better.

text:
Yum, this is great to have around and takes just a few minutes to throw together.  Much quicker then running to the store to get the taco seasoning packet I always seem to forget to buy!  I used 2 rounded tablespoons (2-1/2 Tablespoons if you like to measure exact) of this mix to 1 lb. ground beef.  These are spices I already have and this recipe helps me to use them up before they get bland.  And you can choose the quality of the spices you use in it so you can have a great seasoning mix if you use the better quality spices.  I added a little cayenne pepper 1/8 tsp to a double batch of this.  I think it would be fun to give batches of this away for Christmas along with some salsas and chips, and maybe some margarita mix and call it a Mexican siesta kit.

text:
Even BETTER than a packaged mix!!  

I had a little more than a pound of ground turkey, so I used heaping measurements of all ingredients, except for the salt, which I reduced to 1/2 t., and the black pepper, which I reduced to 1/4 t.  I also ommited the crushed red pepper; this still had plenty of flavor!  

After browning and draining the meat, I added the spices along with 3/4 c. cold water mixed first with 1 t. corn starch.  It came out perfect!!

I never seem to have those little packets on hand, so I will definitely keep this recipe on file to make again and again!

userID:
731723
Display Name:
SZYQ1
isPro:

61

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve been using this recipe for taco seasoning for a while. It is great as written, and much better/healthier than those little taco seasoning packets, which I have not bought in years! I make a large batch of it and store in an airtight container (start with a small batch to adjust seasoning to your preference before you make a lot). I use this mix in different dishes as well and find it easier for me to omit the salt and pepper. I prefer to season meat or other sides with S&P to taste as I’m cooking, especially if adding any canned goods. For those who have issues with spices or heat, omit the red pepper flakes, as we do. You also may want to reduce the chili powder by ¼ to ½, which we have not had a problem with, but everyone’s taste preference is different. In recent months, I have replaced store bought chili powder with Chili Powder by Terri from this site (I use about ½ tbsp. of it for this recipe). If making ground meat tacos (I usually use turkey), brown the meat first, then dust with a little flour, and stir to combine. Add 3 tbsp per 1 lb ground meat, stir to combine, add ¼ - ½ cup water, and stir again. Wait 1-2 minutes, and reduce heat to low to keep warm. Sauce will thicken up while you’re finishing other sides or warming tortillas. Thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
This is just as if not better than the store bought stuff, and probably way cheaper because if you cook a lot you probably have most of it on hand. And if you have to go out and buy anything you can make up a big batch and store it. Taco seasoning is good on more than just tacos! I cut down on the red pepper flakes, in fact when I store it I don't even add the flakes and just add them when I make whatever I'm using the seasoning on. 3tbs to 1lb of meat and 2/3 cup water. It is a little thinner than store bought so I just added a small amount of flour (couple teaspoons) and it thickened right up! Very very good! Best part is you can tweak the taste to however you like!

text:

I browned the meats, drained the fat, and then added about 1/2c of water and all the spice mix and it was just wonderful!  I was skeptical, but I really couldn't taste the difference between this and the chemical and preservative laden spice packets.  DEFINITE KEEPER!!

text:
How I ever used store bought seasoning before I'll never know. This is so much better than any packet out there! I keep a triple batch ready to use anytime. It's great on beef, chicken and turkey. Although, I think shredded chicken thighs are the best. I haven't tried pork yet. The first time I made it for a birthday party taco bar and everyone raves about it, which is why there was so little leftover. I followed the recipe exactly, but found it a little too spicy and salty. I've since omitted the crushed red pepper and halved the salt. Works for our family. I usually triple it and always make sure to have it on hand. I also add diced tomatoes, black beans and frozen corn. It adds great flavor and doubles a pound of meat easily. Don't buy packets! It takes no time and is so much better! It wasn't in the recipe, but I found 3 tbsp. per pound of meat with all the extrasworks well.

city:

country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe numerous times and I absolutely love it!  We will never go back to the packaged mix again.  I use the entire amount listed in the recipe for one pound of ground beef and the flavor is wonderful.  The only slight tweak I make is using 1/8 tsp. of cayenne pepper instead of 1/4 tsp. of crushed red pepper flakes only because that's what I have on-hand and we don't like things too spicy.  I also add 2 tsp. of cornstarch to the dry spices to help everything thicken up while cooking.  I add the spice/cornstarch mixture to one pound of browned, well-drained ground beef and then add 2/3 C of water.  Bring it to a simmer for a few minutes and voila!  Best tasting tacos EVER!  Thank you for the recipe!

This is the best taco seasoning mix I have ever tasted. I have to avoid msg and thus I avoid most package mixes. I use this mix for tortilla soup, tacos, seven layer bean dip, with Greek yogurt as a dip, in fresh salsa, in chilli, with beans and rice and even in scrambled eggs. I increase the serving size to 80 so that I always have it on hand. Everyone loves it. Thank you for sharing such a great recipe, Bill.  I just put some in the slower cooker with some chicken breasts and a batch of my fresh salsa. Wow, it smells so good.

text:
I haven't been able to enjoy tacos in years due to a sensitive stomach that suddenly started reacting to the package mix while I was pregnant with my son. I tried this recipe on a whim just to see if it made a difference. I left out the red pepper flakes and added a teaspoon of corn starch to give it more of a sauce like consistency like you get from the packets. 
It turned out absolutely perfect and didn't upset my stomach. Thank you for giving me back my Taco Tuesdays!

text:
Excellent taco seasoning!  I first made this about a year ago, when i realized too late that I didn't have any packets on hand.  Was so good that I now make it in 50 serving increments to keep on hand (thanks Allrecipes for making that easy to do!).  Like some other reviewers, I leave out the red pepper flakes, and also leave out the onion powder, adding in freshly cut but frozen onions that I keep in the freezer.  For an added nutritional boost I use Boulder Salt in place of the sea salt.

This recipe was fantastic. I only used 1/2 of the salt as I used table salt instead of sea salt and could even go with a little less. Then I added 1/2 TBS flour like another review said, and mixed it all together. I browned 1 lb ground beef, then added 3 TBS of the mix with 2/3 C water. It cooked up perfectly; just like the packets only better. No more packets for our family!! This was a HIT.

We love this!  I make it in large batches and store it in an air-tight container so that I can just use what I want for my recipe.  I have used this in ground beef, with chicken for fajitas, in chicken taco soup, pretty much any recipe that calls for taco seasoning.  I make it without the crushed red pepper flakes, too hot for my 5-year-old, but still so good without them.

text:
This recipe is a bit too spicy and salty for our tastes but it still gets five stars because it's so easy to adjust. After making it a few times I finally cut the chili powder by 1 teaspoon, the salt by half a teaspoon, and the black pepper by half a teaspoon. It's so easy to make a big batch--I quadruple it to keep it on hand. A really nice combination of herbs and seasonings that's useful for many dishes!

This was the best.  I will never buy taco seasoning again.  I added two tsps of flour and 2/3 cup of water.  It was spicy initially but once it cooled the hot flavor went away. It was the perfect flavor.

text:
I have used this recipe over and over again.  I will never buy the packaged stuff again.  I had a taco bar for my birthday party and used this seasoning with lean ground turkey (97% fat free)…everyone loved it and they didn't mind it was turkey.  This will be repeated next year!  I also add 1 tsp of corn starch per batch.  It helps it adhere to the meat and keeps from clumping in storage.

text:
Love this! I hate buying pre-made mixes that have a bunch of additives and unnecessary junk in them so this is a great DIY. I am a cumin lover so I add about 2 tablespoons of that but that is my only change.  Lately I have been just throwing some chicken in the crockpot and covering it with this mixture and cooking it for 4 hours on high or 8 on low then shredding it for chicken tacos.   It comes out CRAZY GOOD!!  I also use the chicken for taco or burrito "bowls".  I have used both boneless/skinless breast and thighs and I think for this particular recipe the thighs come out on top.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1360000.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was entirely to spicy for me and my family. I omitted the red pepper flakes and after it was cooked and found it still to spicy, I added more paprika and cooked  some diced potatoes in with the seasoning and a bit more water until the potatoes were done. Even then it was so hot that I couldn't taste anything else...and I live in New Mexico and am quite used to eating spicy Mexican food. I will not make this again. The leftovers weren't even suitable for my dogs unless I wanted to be cleaning up vomit and diarrhea...all because of the heat factor. I know this recipe has gotten a lot of great reviews, and to each his own, but beware of the heat. Perhaps make it without any red pepper or cayenne, then add those to taste, not by following the recipe.

Owning a very successful restaurant for over 20 years, it takes a lot to impress me with a new recipe. This truly did. Congrats to whomever came up with this one. A big fan here.

I found myself with taco plans and no seasoning packs. Rather than run to the store I googled "taco seasoning" and found this recipe. I truthfully don't believe I'll use packaged taco seasoning again, this was just way too easy, convenient and delicious! Thanks!

text:
I didn't have any taco seasoning packets on hand, so I just looked up a recipe for taco seasoning and saw the five-star rating for this one and decided to give it a try.  Now, I won't buy any more expensive packets.  This was awesome.  I doubled the recipe, and the only change I made was that I used ground cayenne pepper instead of red pepper flakes, so I only used about 1/4 tsp. but you can adjust accordingly.  I used all of what I made with 1.25 lb. of browned ground beef, added about half a cup of water, let it simmer for about 10 minutes, and it was simply delicious!  It's so much better than the packet seasoning mix (and probably better for you, too), and most of us probably have all of these ingredients in their pantry--I did.  Thanks for sharing.

I was in a hurry, I didn't know I was out of taco seasoning, so I didn't get a chance to read the reviews as well as I usually do. I did read a few though and took bits from each. 
I doubled the batch for 3 lbs of ground beef. I doubled all the ingredients except - I tripled the garlic, cut the salt and pepper down  a little and substituted cayenne pepper for the red pepper. I added some Better than Bouillon to the meat while it was cooking. I also mixed a little flour in a jar with water and poured that over it.
Turned out wonderful.

text:
All I can say is WOW!  I have tried so many taco seasoning recipes.  They have all fallen short in one way or another.  But not this one.  It is perfect.  My husband didn't even realize it wasn't the package....he has always known in the past.  I was curious how much to use per pound.  Fortunately, another reviewer had already figured that out for me....3 tbl per pound and 2/3 cup water per pound.  I did add a little flour (I used whole wheat) when cooking to thicken up a little.  It was perfect!!  No sugar!  No chemicals! Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!

text:
I gave this 5 stars because you can do a few slight tweaks to perfect it for your family. For my family, I reduced the pepper flakes by 1/2 and added a Tbs. of cornstarch to the mix. Used 1 Tbs. per 1/2 lb. of meat, then added some to the black beans I was preparing on the side. Since I am on a salt restricted diet, this was perfect because I could manage the sodium and know exactly how much I was eating. Thanks for this recipe, Bill. This recipe is putting tacos back into our regular rotation.

text:
I was a little weary of making my own taco seasoning b/c I thought "How can it be just as good as packaged?" Well, let me tell you it's not.... It's BETTER than packaged. I followed the suggestions by FoodSlave on June 5,2006 which increased the garlic & onion & added beef bullion. I also added cornstarch as recommended by FoodSlave to help the seasoning adhere to the meat mixture. It was fantastic! I made a triple batch in a pint jar & will keep it on hand for my "go to" Taco Seasoning! Thanks!

text:
I have found so many uses for this recipe.  I'm very happy to have a cheaper and healthier alternative to the packets.  I put this in chili, season chicken and fish with it, put in Mexican chicken soup, rice, everything.  I even tried it in grits....do not try it in grits (duh).

I used this in my recipe for a taco dip!!!  I used hot Mexican chilli powder (in place of chilli powder)  and McCormick's 5 Firey Pepper Flakes instead of crushed red pepper flakes.  I mixed the dry mix with sour cream and spread it on a cookie sheet.  Then I use Ortega taco sauce and spread a generous layer of that on the sour cream mixure.  Next a layer of grated cheese your choice of what kind.  Share with nacho chips:)  LOVE IT!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Make a huge batch of this stuff and keep it handy!  It is liberating to be able to control the sodium level in foods, so I make this recipe without the salt (haven't missed it yet). To make the seasoning mix finer, I grind the red pepper flakes, which helps release the flavor.  We use about 1/4 cup per pound of ground beef and it tastes even better than the premixed packs at the store.  
If you really want to control your ingredients, make your own chili powder since most commercial blends use salt at a primary ingredient, I recommend the recipe at food.com.
