text:
This worked great! I added about 1/2 tsp cayenne for extra heat, and 1 tbs corn starch to thicken the sauce.

I made veggie tacos with diced mushrooms & zucchini. I sauteed the veggies with onion, garlic, & hot portugal pepper, then added a good 2/3rds of the taco seasoning and enough water to make a sauce (about 3/4 cup). Threw some kidney beans in and let it all simmer while I got toppings ready (tomatoes, lettuce, red pepper, cheddar cheese). 

The result was DELICIOUS. I'll never go back to the packaged stuff! Thanks!

Excellent!  I doubled the garlic and onion (used minced for both) and halved the salt.  Also, added in half a cube of chipotle seasoning (like a boullion cube, purchased in a Spanish market).  

Used a mortar and pestle to lightly grind everything up.  Coated some chicken strips with this, grilled them, served them over salad greens with some corn, shredded cheese, broken up taco shells, and Margarita dressing, from this site.  Yummm!!  Teens loved it, too.

text:
This is really good, and it's now my go-to instead of packets.  
I give 4 stars only because I don't use it exactly as written.  I omitted the black pepper due to an allergy.  I also omitted the oregano after the first time, because I felt like it was an odd flavor to add to a Mexican dish.  Maybe not...but I associate oregano with Italian dishes.

Thanks for a great recipe!

I ran out of taco seasoning so I went here because I love this site! Now I never need to buy taco seasoning again. It is so good. The first time I made it I didn't have any crushed red peppers and it was still very good. You do not have to have them. The next time I made it I used the crushed red peppers in the package from the pizza place. Either way there is no more need for a packaged seasoning again! I think I use about half of the recipe per time. I usually cook about 3/4 lb per use.

As Bill Echols said, "use as little or as much as you want." So, I did precisely that. Increased garlic & onion powders to 1 tsp each, decreased black pepper to 1/2 tsp, substituted 1/4 tsp dried cilantro for the oregano (don't care for it), and kept everything else the same. Wonderful, easy, and darn good! I'll be using this seasoning again!

text:
I have recently decided to switch to a healthier lifestyle and have switched from ground beef to ground turkey. In my research for new ground turkey recipes, I came across tacos. I have never made tacos at home, nor have I ever bought packaged taco seasoning since I prefer to make a lot of my food from scratch. I decided to search for a homemade taco seasoning and came across this one. It had lots of reviews and really high ratings so I gave it a chance with my ground turkey. I made a quick black bean and corn salsa while the turkey was browning and dinner was done. Voila! Not only was it delicious, but I think that was the fastest from scratch dinner I've ever made. Thanks!

This was an excellent combination of spices.  I used the entire mix for 25 oz. 93% lean ground beef, plus 2/3 cup pulverized canned tomatoes, one packet of Splenda, one can of Fritos bean dip, and a generous handful of chopped onions (1 c +)all mixed together and cooked until the meat was thoroughly cooked.  I didn't drain it (I usually have to add some liquid to that lean of beef, hence the tomatoes and bean dip) Delicious on white corn baked shells.  Thanks - it's a keeper!

text:
Yum - husband and I really liked. I was confused on how much to use for how much meat. I used a package of 19.5 oz of ground turkey but I think this seasoning is for 1 Ib of meat. I also followed another reviewers recommendation and added 2/3 cup water after browning and adding seasoning. I let sit simmering in a covered pan for 10 or so minutes. A reviewer said it was too salty. I am not a big fan of salt so I followed their recommendation and cut by half. Not sure if this was necessary as I added more salt after cooking. Ingredients are great as is. Will NEVER buy packaged again - I feel so much better knowing exactly what is in my food!

text:
Delish! Perfect mixture of seasonings and 100 times better than anything from a store-bought packet.  I took the advice of another review and added 1.5 teaspoons of flour to my mix and then added it to 93% ground beef.  Liked that it wasn't a drippy, greasy mess.  Definitely will make again.  Oh, but don't use anything other than sea salt.  I used Kosher b/c I didn't have any sea and it was a tad too salty.

None
country:
None
text:
I really don't understand the great reviews on this - this recipe needs a lot of work. It is too salty, it uses way too much chili powder, and even though you're using *too much* of some things it comes out flavorless. Also, without any thickener and liquid it's just some dry grainy stuff spread unevenly over the meat... these spices (especially all the chili powder) need liquid to even out. I added cornstarch and probably 1/2 cup of water. I do think that the 1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes is a nice amount of spice for the family to share.

None
text:
This was a great starting block to make my own taco seasoning. We make tacos at least 2-3 times a month and it made more sense to make our own now. I bought slightly more expensive ingredients (because I know they are fresh) but I think that the cost difference is unbeatable for us. I usually only use half a tablespoon/whole tablespoon for a pound of turkey meat so I get my moneys worth. After getting it together for how we would eat it, the flavor was unbeatable, and even the reheating of the meat was better. It didn't just stay a blob in the dish. Would recommend this to anyone for 100% following the recipe or for a good starting block.

text:
I mix up a big batch of this seasoning, store it in a jar in the fridge, and use it whenever I make tacos. I add 3 tablespoons mix and 2/3 cup water to each pound of ground meat (hamburger or turkey breast). It tastes very similar to packaged taco seasoning mix, but much better. I'll never buy the packaged mix again. Thanks for the great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!!! I made tacos tonight and didn't realize until I had already defrosted the ground turkey that I didn't have a packet of seasoning, so I tried this one and it was great.  I diddled with it a bit (I like more cumin and also added about a tsp of brown sugar for roundness.)  Another post mentioned adding cornstarch as a thickener, and it's definitely an option if youre pressed for time want it to come together quickly just like the packet, but for me it was fine just adding the brown sugar and letting it cook down over low heat for about a half hour until most of the liquid evaporated.  A little fresh cilantro chopped into the meat mixture at the last minute and we were sitting down to excellent restaurant quality tacos!!  I don't think I'll be needing the packets anymore - thanks!

country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe.  I made it a couple weeks ago.  There is one glaring flaw in the recipe though.   There is nothing to thicken the seasoning.  You should definitely at a TBSp or two of cornstarch to this mix, because when you're cooking up the meat you have to add water.  If you simply add the cup of water to a pound of ground beef, it comes out very watery.  Add some cornstarch to this to thicken it up and you'll be in for some great tacos.

text:
Ooh, this is good! But I made a few modifications as noted by other reviewers. It IS too salty.  I doubled the garlic and onion powders to 1/2 tsp, changed the red pepper flakes to 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper, and I'd recommend subbing 1 tsp of beef boullion for the salt. (I tried it instead of half of the salt, and it was still too salty.)  Surprisingly, it was better than the packets, and WAY better than the big bottle that we got from a bulk discount store.

I tried this recipe, but made a couple of substitutions.  I omitted the paprika because I was out.  I added ground chipotle pepper for part of the black pepper.  The seasoning was very good. The added smokiness from the chipotle was wonderful.  My kids ate better than they ever do.  They said it tasted like Taco Bell.  I found that amusing, but that is a very good review coming from them. I did not find it to taste like Taco Bell though.  This had so much more flavor and was very good.  I will use this recipe from now on.

text:
Like most who review this recipe, I ran out of the packaged seasoning and turned to this trusted web site for help.  Found it with this recipe!  Thanks so much for sharing!  Very yummy!!  I did follow some suggestions:  used dry onion flakes when I browned the meat (something I always do) so I deleted the onion powder; didn't have red pepper flakes so I used a scant 1/8 tsp. cayenne pepper; and added 1/2 c. water when I added the mixture to the meat then let it cook til the water was gone.  This recipe is defintely a keeper!!

city:

country:
None
text:
Perfect. I can see why this recipe has over 1,000 ratings! I've been trying to cook healthier and so don't want to use pre-made taco seasoning anymore as the salt content is crazy.   This one fits the bill and tastes great. My husband and I are vegetarian and this blends really well with texturized vegetable protein (also called soy crumbles or veggie ground round. This is the vegetarian equivalent of beef ground round).   As the TVP is dehydrated, you add water or vegetable stock to rehydrate it (I used water this time as I was making a taco bake). That added just enough moisture to help the seasonings stick to everything.   Turned out very tasty and even the hubby, who tends to eat lots of salty things, enjoyed it as well. I didn't find it that spicy but omitted the red pepper flakes because we didn't have any.  Thanks for much for posting this!!

text:
This is a great seasoning mix, and very convenient since all of the spices are ones I keep on hand. As others have confirmed, this is better than the store-bought packets! I actually made this because I was out of the packets, but I won't be going back after trying this.  The only change I made was to use dried minced onion instead of onion powder because that's what I had on hand. Next time I might try cutting or eliminating the salt because I don't think I'd miss it with all the other spices. I used the whole mix with about 1 1/2 lb of chicken. It turned out very flavorful and was perfectly spicy that way. Those who don't like their food very spicy might want to cut that ratio in half.

text:
SO GOOD! I took the suggestions of others..cut back on some of the "spicy" ingredients. I halved the paprika, 1/8 tsp pepper flakes, and 1 tsp cumin. After I had all the ingredients together I tossed them in the blender to make the spices all the same size. The flavor turned out PERFECT, little hint of spice but not over powering. I found that this recipe is enough for about 1 lb of meat (2 tablespoons approx). I used 2/3 cups water and about 1 tblsp flour to thicken it up. Just cooked until it was thick. Thank you!

This was very easy. It tastes better than the taco seasoning packets you buy in the store. I substituted 1/8 cayenne pepper for the pepper flakes and just used 1 tsp. of cumin, as the reviewer "I'm Nuts too" said to do. I used 1 # pound ground beef for this recipe. I tripled it, with 4 sons, my husband and company around they ate it quickly.  My husband liked how spicier it was than store bought taco seasoning packets!!  I think I will make some ahead and put in freezer.  It makes 2 Tbsp.-2 1/8 Tbsp.for one recipe- 1# ground beef!!

country:

text:
I'm not exactly sure how to rate this recipe...I made it almost exactly as written with the exception of using 1/4 tsp of salt (to make it low sodium).  It definitely resembled taco seasoning...just feels like it's missing something.  I used the entire recipe for 2 lbs of ground beef (worked out to 4 tbsp, so I think people's conversions are right when they say 2 tbsp to 1 lb ground beef).  I did add a touch of water to it and maybe that is what happened - seemed like it diluted it down or something - yet others on here do the same thing and rate it a 5 star.  I think it needs some sort of thickening added to it - will try to add a sprinkle of flour next time.  But I still think there's a spice missing somehow - perhaps the beef cube like another reviewer mentioned.  I'm not giving up on this recipe as it is "almost" there, and I like the idea of making my own sesasoning.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This recipe is simply awesome! We have used it in the beef for tacos and for our chicken enchiladas as well. I will never buy store taco seasoning again. It does run on the spicy side so if you are not one for very spicy, I would recommend cutting down on the chili powder. I had every ingredient in my spice cabinet which was the reason I tried it in the first place and I'm so glad I did. The recipe makes plenty so you will have leftovers. Your food will not need as much as you would put in if it was a store packet. We used about 1-2 tablespoons depending on the dish.

This was a great seasoning mix, just as good as the packets if not better.  Plus my son can't eat most packaged taco seasoning since it contains wheat and he's allergic, so this is great for him.  I use the entire recipe plus 3/4 cup of water with my browned ground beef.  Yummy!

Update: It's 4 years later and this is still my go-to recipe for taco seasoning!  I can't tell you the last time I used a store-bought packet.  I mix up a quadruple batch at a time and store it in an airtight container so I have it on hand.  Love this recipe!

text:
To make it thicken the way the packet seasoning does, add 1/4 cup of corn flour or fine cornmeal to the mix. And to make it authentic, use Mexican Oregano - a spice that is available usually in small packets in the Mexican section of the grocery store.

text:
This is a really good taco seasoning recipe. My grandson made it. He’s 11. We used 2.25 lbs of lean ground beef. He doubled the seasoning recipe. Before I knew it, he dumped the whole bowl of seasoning in the meat. We added water until it just covered the meat, brought it to a boil, then cooked on low until the liquid evaporated. Just a little spicy for me and baby girl; however, the flavor was delicious. Everyone else loved it as is.

text:
I went to the cupboard to make my taco seasoning when I saw I was out of maltodextrin. Found this recipe and thought I would give it a try. Did not change a thing and it passed the wife's taste test with flying colors. For her taste it could use a little less red pepper flakes but otherwise she liked my “experiment”. Like so many others this will be my go to taco seasoning. Thanks for this recipe.

text:
I first found this 5 years ago and have never turned back. I do add a smidgen of cayenne and a dash of ground mustard to the mix. If using for chicken I add a tad of dried lemon peal. The suggestion of using 3 TBSP per pound and mixing a bit of flour before dusting the meat is what I do as well. Tastes better then any mix in the store. Happy cooking!

country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except for a few recommended changes.  1/2 the amount of salt and used table salt.  I used the flour recommendation (2 tsp) and used 1/3 cup of water.  Not enough ‘gravy’ like so mixed 2 tsp cornstarch with 1/3 cup of water and added that in,,,,,, thickened it up well.   Also omitted the red pepper flakes as the teenagers didn’t want the spice and even with that omission it was still slightly sticky.   I used these recipes amounts for 2 lbs of meat and the seasoning ratio was perfect.

Display Name:
Rebecca

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6864167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this Taco Seasoning Mix 2 times now.  I make it in a large batch and use as needed.  I am Keto, so this mix works well with restricted carbs.  I do add a pinch of Xanthum Gum (keto friendly thickener) to slightly thicken when added to water and cooked ground beef for tacos.  Like other reviewers, I upped the garlic and onion powders a bit -- rounded teaspoons -- I also added 1/2 teaspoon cilantro flakes and a pinch of Xanthum Gum.   I use 2 Tablespoons of this mix (very slightly rounded Tablespoons)  and 3/4 cup water to 1 lb of hamburger.  We love it, it's Keto friendly, it's cheaper, healthier and tastier than the packaged kind!!!  Thank you Bill Echols!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight for seasoning my chili Mac. The recipe I use calls for a packet of taco seasoning but I was all out. This recipe was first to show up when I googled. I followed it exactly, putting all the ingredients into the dish. I had 1lb of hamburger meat in the dish. Honestly, the meal tasted 10x better than using a packet of taco seasoning. I was afraid that since I added all the seasoning to the dish that it would be to salty or the flavor would be to intense. The only complaint my family had was that it was to spicy. Next time I’ll mix the seasoning in a bowl first and use a little less, or cut back on the pepper/chili flakes. Definitely a keeper!!

text:
I will make again. I made some changes to suit a toddler: omitted the pepper flakes and used half of the chilli powder. Also I didn’t have sea salt on hand so used half a teaspoon of table salt. It was a tad saltier than I would’ve liked. However, I will definitely use this over and over again. Totally beats the prepackaged stuff. Also, I added water once I added spice to the browned beef and let it boil down, I didn’t see a need for any thickener. Thank you for the amazingly easy and tasty spice mix!

I was pleasantly surprised; it was pretty good! I ran out of the packaged taco seasoning (I think I use McCormack's but it could be a generic) and, rather than run to the store, I tried this with 1 lb of hamburger. I also substituted Old Bay seasoning for the paprika, red peppers and then added some paprika and crushed red peppers for color and heat.

I'll probably buy packaged seasoning in the future but this worked well in a pinch.

text:
This recipe is so much better than packaged taco seasoning.  I double everything in the recipe except the red pepper flakes, salt and pepper.  I only do 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes (or 1/8 tsp cayenne) 1 tsp pepper and 1 1/2 tsp table salt. I don't love spicy food but if you do you might want to just go ahead and double the peppers.  I combined w 1 Tbsp of corn starch. Added it to 2.5 lbs ground beef and 1 1/2 cups water.  Simmer.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6486366.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is seriously good as written.  The addition of flour or corn starch that others mentioned really isn't necessary to get it to "stick".   I doubled the recipe and added it to about 2.25 lbs of lean ground beef (doubling the onion and garlic powder), and I added a cup of water.  As the water cooked out, the spices just naturally wanted to hang on to the meat.  I ended up with a pretty strong flavor, which I loved, but I do think I could have used 3 lbs of meat with a good result.  As for the salt, you could reduce it or leave it out completely to suit your taste or health requirements.  

I swear I will never buy a packaged taco seasoning again unless I'm desperate.

3

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this taco seasoning! I’ve been using this for 2-3 years and haven’t bought the store bought stuff since. It’s so easy, especially since I discovered the bulk spices at WinCo—they are so much cheaper than buying the bottles of spices!!! I don’t add salt to mine and it still tastes fine. Sometimes I just eyeball the measurements and it also tastes fine (I prefer to measure but sometimes I’m lazy lol). For the red pepper I usually just have those packets you get from pizza places and I add that. Tonight I’m trying chipotle powder instead so I’m sure it will be awesome!! I also usually add extra garlic and onion. I would say if you are using chicken instead of ground beef or turkey, you might need less seasoning. I have recommended this recipe to a few people and they love it too.

userID:
17212121
Display Name:
lcroft

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good!  I was skeptical with oregano and paprika, wondering how these ingredients would taste in a taco seasoning mix, but all of the flavors mixed well!

I did not alter the recipe, but I did follow GREGSGIRL63 advice, and added 1/2 tablespoon of flour, to the seasoning mix, then poured the seasoning mix over the hamburger. ( I browned one-pound of hamburger and added the entire seasoning recipe to the one-pound of ground beef).  I only added 1/3 cup of water, but do not think 2/3 cup of water would be too much to simmer off. 

It was so good!  I have tried other homemade taco seasoning recipes, and this is the best one so far.

After I cooked everything, I added some sour cream dollops, on top of finished ground beef mixture, and some Picante, and shredded cheese, and left the heat on low for a minute or two, then turned off heat and put aluminum foil over the top of skillet.  After a few minutes, I spooned some of the mixture into taco shells.  All the toppings I wanted were all together, warmed, and melty!

Thank you!

5

This is the best homemade taco seasoning I’ve ever made! 
I didn’t have onion powder so I just doubled the garlic powder and instead of paprika (which I didn’t have) I used a 1/8 tsp of cayenne pepper. I omitted the red pepper flakes as well. And added 1/2 tbsp of flour as suggested by another reviewer. 
Drained the meat. Added 2/3 cup water and simmered 3 more minutes. Perfection!

This is our GO TO taco seasoning!  I've been using this recipe for years.  It's fantastic for ground meat tacos, fajitas, taco soup - you name it!!  I make this is a giant batch and store it in the freezer for use.  I typically use about 3-4 tablespoons per 2lbs of ground beef - more or less to taste.    I also do not add the salt until I'm making the meals.

text:
It’s awesome. I made a vegan rice dish with sautéed onions, peppers, corn and triple bean mix. I added two teaspoons of the taco seasoning (for about 1 1/2 cups of rice) while sautéing the veggies. I just dumped everything in the pressure cooker. I did add extra salt before cooking. After the rice was cooked I added some lime juice and garnished with cilantro. Not only did people love the dish but they took away the little rice that was left.

I took the advice in other reviews, I double the garlic and onion...the only variation is what type of paprika I have on hand... smoked, spanish, once used hot hungarian...had to dilute the heat by making a mammoth batch and adding it to it...  My children are grown but whenever I come to visit the empty "Mom's Taco Seasoning" container is on the counter and I know one of my first missions is to refill...we just can't go back to the store bought version.   It is so versitile, add a little to chili recipe to round out flavor, add it to hamburger soup or taco soup for a nice flavor...heck I've added it to crumbs and dredged my chicken in it! Love this recipe

text:
We recently found out our little one has severe celiac and have been shocked by the amount of things we can’t feed her now. Fast forward a tad bit and we’re finding recipes for all of our favorite things. We made this and tweaked it a bit to our taste likes. Took out the table pepper. Added some minced dryer onion. Happily everyone in our house all loved it. In fact our little one(8yrs) said is better then any of the packet seasonings for tacos she’s ever tried. This will be our go to mix. I made a giant amount and am storing it in a giant mason jar at home. This way we can just grab the jar and scoop out the amount we need per taco night making.

This is all we ever use for tacos. Guests rave about  how delicious this seasoning is. The only changes we have made were omitting the red pepper flakes and halving the black pepper (we have children who do not care for a lot of heat). We mix about 1.5 T per lb of meat along with 1t of cornstarch (to thicken the sauce) and 2/3 c of water.

text:
You can't go wrong he re - and you can increase or decrease any of the seasonings to your liking. But it tastes so much fresher and better than the packets you get at the store. Go ahead and make up a big batch (I quadrupled) and put it in a jar for quick use. I've used this twice with shredded chicken breast for a yummy taco night. Just add already cooked chicken and some stock or broth to a pot and as much seasoning as you like. Heat it up on low and perfect chicken taco fillings (or topping for nachos or filling for burritos or quesadillas. As you can tell, I could eat this almost every day.

text:
This is a great recipe to avoid gluten in prepackaged taco seasoning & to reduce extra packets in my pantry.  HOWEVER, consider that you should be using dried chili powder instead of the chili powder blend that many of us in the US are used to—that is just a mix of cumin, oregano, onion & garlic.  You may have to look at an ethnic grocery, but it definitely will kick it up a notch!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would give this more stars if there were instructions on how to use it.  I followed a users advice and put 1/2 Tb of flour in it, then 3T per 1 pound of ground meat with 2/3 cup of water and found this way over-seasoned.  But the flavor was on target.  I have some left over and will try it again but about 1.5 Tb per pound of meat. Also I omitted the red pepper flakes as my kid doesn't like things too spicy and it was still too spicy for him.  So beware if you're looking for something mild.

text:
My family LOVE this recipe. I did make changes, but not much. I used freshly ground Ancho Chile Peppers, and freshly ground Cumin. The pepper amount I kept the same, but the cumin I cut in half because the scent was so strong, I did not want to over power the seasoning. Doubled up on the garlic, added smoked paprika instead of the plain paprika and left out the red pepper flakes. I don't really care for hot spicy sauces. 

Next time I will try grinding up the Cascabel Chiles to see if there is a taste difference. God is so amazing, He gave us a HUGE variety of spices to try, we are incredibly blessed!!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2731226.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, and I always have some on hand to season meat or beans! I quadruple the recipe (adjust it to make 40 servings), and it fits perfectly in an 8 ounce mason jar. After it's made up, just use 2 - 3 tablespoons per pound of meat (or beans) with 2/3 cup water and let simmer until the liquid is absorbed. 

I like the recipe just the way it is, but my spice-averse mother preferred it with less red pepper flakes than the recipe calls for. Another variation is to substitute something like chipotle or ancho chili powder for some of the regular chili powder. This recipe is really versatile, so feel free to mix it up!

text:
Having never made from-scratch Taco Seasoning, at first I was pretty skeptical as I had always bought Old El Paso seasoning. I was tired of the salt content, even on the "lower sodium" version. Finally, I decided to give homemade seasoning a try, and this was literally the first recipe that came up. I made the recipe exactly as it states, with the exception of using No Salt (a salt-free substitute) instead of Sea Salt... and the results were amazing! It was very flavourful without being over-powering and being able to adjust the amount of salt used was a  fantastic change. Like it hotter? Add more red pepper flakes. Want it for dips and taco salads? No problem! I have no need to go looking for another taco seasoning recipe, ever. Great job, Sir!

text:
This was kind of perfect. I didn't know I could get such good results from making my own taco seasoning.  I followed the recipe as written except added only 1/2 t salt because I read some the other reviews. It was more than enough. I also added 2 t cornstarch to help it cling to the meat. We are trying to go meat free in the house so I used the entire recipe to season 12 ounces of "crumbles" to which I added about 5 ounces of ground turkey.  It turned out so well. Definitely a keeper.

Excellent recipe thank you! Switched sea salt to kosher salt. Sea salt is very inconsistent, we had fine sea salt and it was a little salty. I have learned either use same amount as called for in recipe using kosher salt, kosher salt is very consistent, or cut in half when using table salt.

text:
Like a lot of people here, I reached in the pantry to grab a pack of taco seasoning and didn't have any. Looked up "best taco seasoning" and this one had the most reviews that I saw. The only thing I left out while putting this together was the addition of red pepper flakes. I read through a few of the reviews and opted to add a half tablespoon of flower suggested by the top review. My daughter is fairly particular about her tacos, and this recipe passed with flying colors. She went back for seconds....and me too. I may play with it and tweak it a little, because I love to do that with recipes, but as is, this one is a keeper. Thanks for posting this recipe Bill.

text:
I made this exactly to the recipe except that  I used table salt as I was out of sea salt.  Because I am a vegetarian I used Trader Joe's beefless ground "beef" crumbles instead of hamburger meat.  My tacos  turned out great, almost like the real thing...yummy!  This recipe makes just the right amount for a pound of meat so in order to save time I'm going to increase the servings by a lot and store it in a sealed container.  Thank you for a good money-saving recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4/11/17  I thought it was very good but not fabulous. It sure is not as salty as the packets at the store. But it's SO MUCH HEALTHIER than store bought. I read the package ingredients and Maltodextrin is the #1 ingredient in Old El Paso 25% less sodium taco seasoning. Do you realize that is MSG? It's a food additive and also used in soft drinks and candy and many other processed foods.  My kids had no idea I made the seasoning and they did not know the difference. I will next time add some corn starch and fresh chili powder instead of my old jar. I also will cut down on the chili powder a tad. Seasonings get old, so fresh seasonings makes a difference.  I also added about a 1/2 cup of water to the almost 1.5 pounds of beef.  Next time I will make more of this and save it as a general seasoning.

text:
Thank you for publishing the ratios.  Sure, I embellished the recipe by taking dried Ancho and guajillo peppers and dehydrating the peppers in 2 cups of water, saving the water, discarding most of the seeds, chopping the peppers, adding a red onion, red, orange and yellow bell peppers,  allowing the oils to release.  Finally, adding the spices and herbs called out in your recipe. 

I use 99% fat free ground turkey as the protein, which takes on the flavors very well.  Due to dryness of the turkey, I add the water from dehydrating the peppers, then tomato paste and diced tomatoes.

region:

country:

text:
I always bought the store packets until I was at a friends one day and forgot to bring the seasoning for our taco night. I had been trying different recipes to try to get away from all the questionable ingredients anyway and this fit the bill. My friends loved the tacos and I was hooked. A few of my preferences-  I do like to spice it up with cayenne instead of paprika. I also add a touch of cinnamon (dont knock it til you try it) and little turmeric hidden in there for added health benefits. Spices are good for you! This is full of them. If youre sensitive to salt, maybe cut it back. My taste buds dont like much salt, so I used 1/2 teaspoon and it allows me to make the dish more flavorful with extra seasoning without drowning in salt. Made a bunch of this stuff last night and added it to my spice rack so its always handy. Thanks for my new favorite taco seasoning recipe!

text:
Mix this up just as stated. Add 2T to a pound of browned, ground meat (works with bison/beef/turkey) that had been cooked with about 1/3 cup chopped onions. Also add about 1T flour and 1/4 C water to help the seasoning "stick," and heat until thickened. Just the right amount of heat. This has been my go-to taco seasoning for a few years now. No need to try any other recipes!

text:
How many times do you get started on a Mexican recipe and open your cupboard to find you're out of those Taco Seasoning packets?  Happens to me all the time - and it kills me to pay so much for 'em....  Well, those days are over.  This recipe uses spices you already have in your spice drawer.  I made up twelve portions in zip lock snack bags - so I'm good to go now!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love love love this seasoning. I first made it in a pinch when I didn't have the envelope. My hubby likes his tacos with plain ground beef (I know! Whaaaat?) so this works great - I pull off his portion and then add as much of this as I want with some water (I use about 1/2 cup water for about 1/2 lb meat). Let it cook down for a bit and the meat is covered with oozy,  seasoned goodness! There is no need to add flour, cornstarch, or anything else to "hold" the seasoning on the meat - just cook for a few minutes like you would if you followed spice packet instructions.  Thanks!

Made and tried this tonight as written. It was awesome! I love salt and I did find this to be a bit too salty for me. The heat from the red chilies was spot on for me but I think was a bit too warm for my toddler. I'm currently making a big batch to have on hand so will put in less salt and red chilies. I can always add more salt if needed while cooking. Thank you for this recipe!! I will not be buying the pre-packaged ones anymore.

This is great as written. It is well balanced, but it's easy to tweak if you like more of  something and/or less of something else. You need about 3T per one pound of meat. If you store it in something air tight, it lasts at least a few months. Definitely a keeper! Thanks,  Bill!  :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good. I cut the cumin down to 1 tsp.  I also doubled recipe so I would have 3 tbsp which is about what you need for 1 lb of ground beef.  I added 1/2 tbsp flour to 3 tbsp of the mix (stir in until incorporated)  and sprinkled it over 1 lb ground beef then added about 2/3 cup water and let it simmer for few minutes.  I omitted the red pepper flakes and it was perfectly spicy so unless you are a big fan of all things spicy I wouldn't add them.   It's so incredibly easy to make and so much better than consuming all those processed preservatives.  This is a keeper!

text:
Excellent!  Always have these ingredients on hand so never need to buy an overly salted package again.  Amounts are easy to adjust to individual tastes.  I don't find it necessary to add cornstarch or flour, but I do add some homemade beef broth (about 1/3 cup for 1.5 pounds of ground beef)and let it simmer with the spices for a few minutes.  Perfect tacos every time!

text:
Love this! It tastes so good! Only thing if you have small kids that don't like it spicy, you'll need to cut down on red pepper flakes (quite a bit....it has a pretty good kick to it, which I love but my kiddos don't). Also, my hubby says it's a little salty, I didn't notice, but if you have heart problems then you could prob 1/2 it & it would still be excellent! Overall I love it & highly recommend! I did 3Tbls seasoning + 1tsp corn starch + 2/3c water per lb of meat & it was perfect!!!

Winner! I don't buy prepackaged taco seasoning anymore! This is healthier, cheaper and tastier. I make big batches so I always have it on hand. I leave out or greatly reduce the crushed red pepper flakes and reduce the salt for a "mild" and "low sodium" version. Include a bit of flour or cornstarch as some suggested - then add to cooked meat with some water as you would the store bought stuff. Perfect!

text:
I like this much more then store bought packets.   My kids don't like things very spicy so I halved the red pepper flakes and skipped the pepper.

I used this entire batch for 1.5lbs of ground beef and used 2/3 cup of water.  After browning the meet and I mean brown.  I remove the meat and in the same dirty pan cook half of a large sweet onion that I diced and a small can of mild green chilies on med heat until the onions are soft.  Then I add the meat, seasoning, tbs of minced garlic and the water.  Simmer for 15 mins or so.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this when I made venison taco meat. YUM! With approximately 2#s of meat, I used a bit more than called for, but not quite doubled. Of course I added extra garlic & onion powder because that's my family's preference. With the venison, to beat any of the "wild game taste," I seasoned the meat with half of the seasoning while browning. Once cooked through on med-low heat, I added the rest of the seasonings with 1/2 cup water (plus just enough) to make sure all of the meat would slightly simmer in some of the juice... mixing a few times, I let the meat simmer in the awesome  flavors for about 5 minutes (until I had all the fixings ready)... Called everyone to come grab a plate & there wasn't a drop left. Enjoy! :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3379824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent spice mix but in my opinion the salt measurement needs to be increased, maybe doubled.  I've made it twice now and both times I thought it needed to be saltier.   Next time I will increase the salt by at least half.  A very easy way to use this is with a Boston Butt Roast.  Just trim excess fat, coat the entire thing in this spice mix and throw it in the crock pot.  You may brown it in a pan first of course, but this is not really necessary.  The spices caramelize quite nicely and no liquid needs to be added as the pork will release a lot of juices.  6-8 hours later, I just shred it in it's own juices.  This makes really excellent shredded pork for tacos, burritos or enchiladas!  Thanks for a great recipe, no more taco seasoning packets for me :)

I followed directions exactly, although I usually tweak up recipes.  I used the whole thing on a pound and a half of ground turkey.  Didn't measure, just sprinkled!  My family likes things spicy, so this worked.  If you don't like spicy, lower the amount of red pepper flakes.  I've now made a large batch to store and use next time!  Whole family loved it!  And for any carb-free cooks out there, this is great because there's no sugar in it!  The store bought brands have sugar, which is a no-no on my husband's current diet! Made a great taco salad!!

text:
I'm trying to get my picky 4-year-old to try new things and *gasp* get used to food groups touching each other. So tacos seem like a good way to start. I made this for dinner tonight but omitted all of the spicy ingredients except for the paprika, which I only used 1/4 teaspoon of. I also added 1 teaspoon of cornstarch and 1/3 cup of water to the ground beef to thicken it up a bit. It was a hit! Mr. Picky had THREE tacos! I'll be making this again!

text:
Perfect!  I needed a tablespoon of taco seasoning for jalapeños poppers and didn't have any so I had to look up a recipe for it. This is perfect for any recipe that calls for taco seasoning. The only change I make is increase the salt to a tablespoon. It's not too much salt and helps enhance the flavor. I quadruple the recipe and keep a jar of this in my cupboard for extra flavoring in Mexican cooking.

userID:

Display Name:
lk718

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe to make your own! So much better than the packets of taco seasoning you buy at the store that I will never buy another one. It doesn't take long at all to toss this together. I halved the chili powder, doubled the garlic, onion, and red pepper flakes. The biggest change I made, though, was getting rid of the cumin altogether. I find that it overpowers most taco recipes and was so pleased without it. To give the seasoning more body I added 1/4 teaspoon beef bouillon and halved the salt. Very yummy! A note to those who don't love spicy - 1 teaspoon of pepper is a lot! At least cut it in half if you have milder tastes. Personally, I love the 1 teaspoon! I mix all that with about 1/4 cup water and pour over a bit over a pound of ground turkey... So delicious!
Review:
Rating:
5

I made it as stated except I switched Kosher salt for sea salt (all I had) and decreased it by about 1/4 tsp.  I thought this was good but my kids thought it was a little too spicy.  Next time, I'll just put in 1/8 tsp of crushed pepper or back off the chili powder.  I thought it needed a little more salt but that was my fault since I backed off.  Next time, it will be followed to the letter with just less heat.  I followed top reviewers advice and used 3 Tblsp of mix and 2/3 cup water.  Beef came out perfectly and I had just a little bit of mix left.

Thank you so much for sharing this excellent spice mix recipe!!! I doubled it and added a packet of Goya beef bouillon, about 1 Tbsp. each of dried minced onion and AP flour, while using only about 1/2 tsp. of coarse Kosher salt. Also omitted the red pepper flakes and used about an 1/8 tsp. of cayenne pepper as certain people in my house can't tolerate especially spicy food! Can't wait to use this weekend on tacos/nachos!!!! This will be my permanent taco seasoning go-to, as I had every ingredient at the ready in my pantry!

text:
Excellent! We triple the recipe and store it in our spice cabinet. This is our go-to taco seasoning. Our favourite is to sprinkle it over browning ground chicken or turkey (to taste - we like it spicy and use about 2 tablespoons per pound of meat) for soft tacos. Add a couple tablespoons of water if the meat is too dry. Serve with soft corn tortillas, shredded cabbage/lettuce, salsa, cheese and crema, and never be satisfied with restaurant tacos again! This is one of our favourite recipes on All Recipes. It's also excellent on grilled chicken breast for a killer taco salad.

I started to make this recipe and then read a review stating it was quite spicy and salty so I decided to double the recipe except I didn't add any additional salt or crushed red pepper. 

After cooking I added the seasoning and tried it. Taste was really good but it is SPICY! I'm not a big spice lover but I can handle slightly.. I'll definitely use this recipe again but I may cut out the red pepper altogether. Especially if I plan on feeding it to little people.

text:
I always do as other reviewers suggest--I've learned that always helps.  Anyway, I doubled the garlic & onion powder--a very good tip. You don't  necessarily need to do that if you like using fresh onion/garlic.  I browned 1# lean ground beef, added 1 finely diced roma tomato, a little diced bell pepper, a little diced fresh onion, & 1/2 a can of tomato sauce.  Since I like fresh onion & fresh garlic, next time, I'll stick to the original version of the recipe.  I tasted the meat when it was ready to serve & added 1 tsp of sugar to balance out the flavor.  I think that's the only change I'll make, other than omitting the pepper flakes.  (My husband gets heartburn.) I almost forgot...I'll reduce the cumin next time also.

Great mix but too much heat for my family. I doubled all ingredients with the exception of  chili powder and red pepper. Instead of 1 Tbs of chili powder,  I used 1 tsp and omitted red pepper flakes. Also, replaced paprika with a smoked paprika for a little different flavor. Kids loved it on taco meat - added tiny amount of corn starch and water to taco meat so it made a thicker sauce.

text:
I've used this recipe twice now and my husband and I love it. My husband didn't know that I had substituted this recipe for the packaged seasoning the first time I did it and he asked me what I did to make the flavor so good. I will definitely use this recipe from now on. The only change I made was substituting chipoltle chili pepper flakes and Ancho chili powder. I also added 1 tsp cornstarch to the mix. I mixed up 4x the recipe and stored it in a glass container. Next time i will make a bigger batch to have on hand because we have tacos and enchiladas often.

I thought I would give this a try instead of using the seasoning packet that I normally buy.   It was great because it used spices that I always have in my cabinet.   I thought the flavor was good and had a nice heat from the red pepper flakes.   It was REALLY salty for our taste though.   I ended up added some water to the beef to try and dilute it , but, it didn't help.   I will make this again, but, for our taste I will cut the salt amount in half.  (I did use the sea salt listed in the recipe and not table salt.)  UPDATED:  7/21/17 Tried again this time reducing the salt and it was much more to our liking.  I will be using this instead of the packet from now on.

I add a little bit of water along with the mix when I add it to the meat to help it cook into it.  It tastes great on ground turkey and shredded chicken.  When using it with ground beef, I have to use a double batch.

text:
This recipe is equivalent to one packet of Taco Seasoning. I adapted the recipe to make extra:
4 Tbsp of chili powder; 1 tsp garlic powder; 1 tsp onion powder; 1 tsp oregano; 2 tsp paprika; 2 tbsp cumin powder; 1 heaping tbsp salt; and 1 heaping tbsp of pepper. 
Use 2 Heaping tbsps of ingredients for 1 Taco Seasoning packet!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is it, the recipe I was looking for.  Taco night is everyone's favorite and my kids ask that I don't use the pre-packaged stuff any more.  We like ours highly seasoned, but only medium-hot, so I cut back on the red pepper flakes and use about 3 tbsp. per pound of meat.  I also cut the amount of salt and black pepper.  After the meat is browned and drained, I add some water and the seasoning mix, plus a sprinkling of flour to add a little 'body.'  Heat while stirring until the water cooks away, then remove from heat just before the mixture starts to stick to the pot. Delicious.

text:
Whenever I make tacos, I add a can of refried black beans or pinto...  When I can, I use my own cooked black beans and take the "stick" blender to make them similar to refried beans consistency. This thickens the taco meat without flour or cornstarch, while adding fiber and more nutrients. 

Of course I tweak the recipe to my liking. I add fresh onions and peppers to the recipe.

Thank you for sharing this recipe. My rating is based on a personal preference for less cumin flavor in my taco seasoning. I found it a bit too heavy. To lessen it, I doubled the chili, garlic, and onion powders, and salt. I ended up with just under 1/4 c of seasoning. I used all of it for two pounds of meat. I just needed to sprinkle a little bit more sea salt on it. I also added 1/2 c of water to the meat with the seasoning, and let it simmer a while. It was very good! Good amount of heat!

country:
None
text:
Ridiculously good and easy to follow. The original recipe is really good.

I normally do tweak it a little - less ground cumin and more cayenne pepper instead of paprika. I am not a huge fan of cumin and when I put about 3/4 teaspoon of ground cumin instead of 1 1/2 teaspoons of ground cumin. I feel that the flavor of cumin is not overpowering of other spices this way and they all just come together very nicely. And I put about 1 teaspoon of cayenne pepper instead of 1/2 teaspoon paprika because I like my food spicy. And I really like it this way. Fellow spicy food lovers,  go ahead and do substitute the portion of paprika to cayenne pepper. It works out great!

text:
This was an excellent Taco seasoning, my family has requested that I use this from now on.
I did add a couple of things; I put 2 Tablespoons of cornstarch and one teaspoon of Beef granules or powder to the seasonings. I also left out the Red Pepper flakes ( already spicey) and cut the salt down to 1/2 teaspoon (was a little too salty with a teaspoon).    When added to my meat mixture I add  2/3 cup of water and let simmer for a few minutes.  Yum Yum! Better than any Taco packet or restaurant!

text:
This is now my go-to taco seasoning recipe.  My son has celiac disease, and so we aren't able to use a lot of prepackaged seasonings.  I was looking for a seasoning that I could make that he could eat, and this one fit the bill.  Ever since I first made this one, I often go back to it, even when we have a gluten-free package in the pantry!

text:
I don't  usually write reviews for recipes but this seasoning did not disappoint!  We decided tacos would be a good meal to make tonight as my boyfriend was inviting a friend over for dinner and it would be a cheap way to feed everyone. I substituted about a forth of a  large yellow onion and a tbsp of minced garlic for the onion and garlic powder.  I poured a little olive oil in the pan and sautéed the onion and garlic in the oil until translucent before adding the seasoned meat. Everyone loved it! Thanks so much!

text:
According to my taco loving child this "tastes the same" as the packaged stuff. I ran out today and didn't feel like buying more, so I decided to give this recipe a try. I'm glad I did. I didn't have any crushed red pepper, onion powder, or paprika but I was able to sub in equal parts of the Epicure Salsa Seasoning for both the red pepper an onion powder. I also reduced the salt a little because of this substitution. I also used 3 Tbsp per pound of ground beef. It worked perfectly! Thanks so much.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a staple in our house. I Make a huge batch and it keeps for months. (Also a great gift for the cooks in your life.) If you want the conversions for a large batch, here is what they are:
3&3/4 C chili powder
1/3 C garlic powder
1/3 C onion powder
1/3 C oregano
1/3 C red pepper flakes or to taste
1/2 C paprika
  2 C cumin
1/4 C each S & P
Throw into mason jars for storing.

text:
This is excellent! Tastes a lot better than the packaged seasonings and is very low in sodium!  Add 1/2 tsp. of cayenne pepper if you want to spice it up a bit.

I use about  3-4 Tbsp. per pound of meat.  I also add about 1/3 cup of water and 1 Tbsp. of potato starch (could use corn starch or flour instead) to the cooked meat to create a thickened sauce.

text:
Have been trying to use less packaged mixes. So great that I was out of taco seasoning mix tonight, as I went to the computer and trustworthy recipes.com had this recipe! I might not have tried it otherwise, it was great, I had almost all of the ingredients on hand, just have to tweek it a little I think. My husband and I thought a little something was missing, might be that I was out of garlic powder and used garlic seasoning instead. I liked other reviewers suggestion of adding the flour or cornstarch, will try that next time and maybe either tomato paste or a little brown sugar (or dash of cocoa?) to see what difference it makes. Will definitely keep using it.

text:
I loved this recipe.  After coming from the grocery store, I realized that I didn't have the packaged stuff so I rushed to my computer to find a homemade taco seasoning mixture and this one came up.  As I looked at the ingredients, I realized that I had all of the ingredients, so I thought.  I substituted cayenne pepper for the pepper flakes since my daughter doesn't like food that is too spicy.  Also, I didn't have any chili powder so mixed all of the dry spices in a bowl before adding them to my chopped chicken and once I added the mixture to the partially cooked chicken, I poured some refrigerated Chili Sauce directly on the meat in the skillet and let it simmer in with the rest of the spices.  It was delicious!   No more packages for this momma on taco night!

text:
The ingredients list gave me a starting point but I changed at least half of the amounts, so I can't rate it 5 stars. Here's what I did:

(For about 4 lbs of beef)
2 tbs cumin
2 tbs chili powder
1 tbs onion powder
1 tbs garlic powder
1 tbs Himalayan pink salt (saltier than table salt I think)
1 tsp black pepper
1 tsp red pepper flakes
1 tsp dried oregano
2 tsp paprika

Very delicious. Saving this recipe.

I'm used to the louder mixes from the store, but this recipe makes for a MUCH better taco!  Easy to tweak to your liking, as well.

I don't use the packets since I found out that if "spices" are listed most likely this will include MSG which I do not use in my cooking.  I was hard pressed to find a good alternate until tonight. I did increase the garlic and onion powders to 1/2t (do not confuse with garlic and onion salt as they are 2 different things.  Everyone enjoyed the flavors and the amount of heat. This is a sure winner in my recipe box.  I immediately made a 4X recipe and put it in a shaker box and will use it again and again.

text:
I made the recipe exactly as written. It was very good and not "chemical" tasting as some of the packets are. The only thing I would do next time is halve the salt. It was a bit salty for my taste (and I like salt)! I recipe made just over 2 TBS which is equivalent to one packet of taco seasoning mix. I used it in a pot of taco soup and it was very good. As some others said, there is a kick to it, but I liked that. I think the kick will mellow a bit if you halve the salt, though.

text:
I loved this - mainly because I love the idea of this. I'd been buying packaged taco seasoning for many years, but now that I've actually been cooking for a while, I love the idea of cheaper home-made equivalents to packaged food products. I looked up the directions on McCormick's own website, and basically used the whole batch (I made it exactly as written) for one pound of ground beef. (I actually made burritos with this instead of tacos.)  My palate's not too sensitive, but this tasted just like the real thing to me. I always have these spices on hand, so I'll never go back!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This seasoning mix is fabulous!!  I have always used prepackaged mixes, but since going gluten free that is no longer an option.  This recipe was so much better than any prepackaged mix I have ever used!  I did omit the onion powder and garlic powder in favor of using fresh.  I sauteed my onion and garlic in a little olive oil then put in 1 lb of ground grass fed beef and just added the seasoning directly to the meat.  Putting it in before the meat was browned allowed for the seasoning to really flavor the meat.  I didn't need to add any kind of thickener or water using this method.

My husband asked me to please do something else with our tacos this evening, so I gave this a whirl.  I didn't measure, just eyeballed, and he said it was great!  I had almost everything on hand (omitted the onion powder because I was out) and it was so easy.

text:
This is a great place to start if you want to start making your own taco seasoning. I have always bought the packets, but I would like to cut out processed foods like that.
I added in more onion powder and garlic powder. Also added a little smoked paprika in addition to the regular paprika.
You need something to help the seasoning coat the meat. I used cornstarch when I mixed the seasoning with the meat (not pre-mixed in) but flour would also do the trick.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this recipie.  I have tried quite a few taco seasonings and they never came out nearly as good as this.  This did come out a little too hot, but I think that was because there are huge differences in how and where you get chili powder. I was using pure Indian chili powder where most chili powder in American stores are much older and weaker and a mix of different types of chilis.  I should have known to cut it down I would never even consider using this much even in super hot curry.  I guess you could just use less mix but then you will have to give up the other flavors and like someone else said I am a garlic/onion lover and I would not want to give up that flavor.  Better to adjust the powder than cut down flavor.
  But since my family likes HOT food, they just added a little extra sour cream to reduce the heat.  Next time I will stick to 1/2 a tbsp.  I made a batch to keep on hand and i also skipped the red chili flakes.  Never like them and they are redundant considering you already have chili powder. If you have kids who like the toco bell type you can consider adding 1/4 tsp of corn starch it will give it the texture they are used to.  My kids love it that way, but not me.

text:
I've got to throw in with the lovers!  I made the full recipe and added 2 t cornstarch to more equal the packet that I USED to use.  Then I divided the mixture in half, and added it to 1/2 lb cooked ground beef (I was making a small batch of tacos for lunch) along with 1/3 C water (2/3 C for the whole batch as per other suggestions).  It cooked up "saucy" as I'm used to, and I thought it had a nice kick -- not too spicy, tho we eat spicy in this household. And I, too, am never going back to packets!  Thanks for this!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm disappointed in this one. A general suggestion of how much to use per pound would be nice, instead of "use as little or as much as you want." I used the whole batch, 1 ounce, in 3 pounds of beef for a big Mexican themed Christmas dinner. Considering a store bought pkg. is 1 ounce per 1 pound beef, I was actually worried it would turn out too mild, but I figured it was a safe bet for the kids. Wrong. The adults enjoyed it, although a few of us thought it was too salty and had an after kick. Unfortunately, the kick was way too hot for the kids, and my kid safe dish suddenly was being picked at and they were guzzling juice and complaining...the opposite of what I wanted. The proportions are off somewhere on this, and I'm not going to bother trying to experiment with it. Bottom line: If you try this, don't assume an ounce of this is equal to an ounce of a seasoning packet.

Simply delicious as is! I did add 2 tsp of flour to help the mix cling to meat but it is not necessary. After draining the grease, I add 3 tbsp of the seasoning and 1/3 cup of water to 1lb of browned ground beef. it was not too salty or too spicy as some reviews mention...this maybe because i added the flour to my mix. Thanks for this recipe!

Delicious!  And for pennies on the dollar, I will never purchase a packet of taco seasoning again!  One reviewer commented that the mix is very spicy as is, and he/she is correct.  I think next time I would reduce the red pepper flakes.  I think next time I am going to try making two pounds of taco meat, using 6 tablespoons of taco seasoning (reduce the red pepper flakes), and throw in a can of Ro-Tel with green chiles, blended, in place of some of the water.  I don't mind the chunks of tomatoes, but the DH probably would.  Thanks for sharing this recipe.  It's a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only tweaks I made to the recipe was that I substituted cayenne pepper for the paprika, since I didn't have any paprika on hand and I also used regular table salt.  I added the whole thing to about a pound of browned and drained lean ground beef with about a half cup of water, brought to a boil and then let simmer for five minutes.  

Very tasty.  Spicy, but not super spicy.  Probably a touch hotter than the "hot" seasoning mixes I've tried from the store.  I've made recipes that utilize beef broth, stock, etc and they are tasty, but I wouldn't say better,just different.  I like a drier taco, the beef stock recipes generally make a juicer sort of meat.

text:
11/14/2012 Great recipe, it was a little heavy on salt - will reduce salt in next batch. I used this in ground beef for Mexican Lasagna. Much better than store bought taco seasoning. The recipe for Seven Layer Taco Dip in the bean layer. I'll make a LOT more of this and package some as gifts. 11/22/2016 - I made a LOT the second time - and lowered the salt, which took away intensity. This time when making a LOT (175 servings) For this size - the salt is 1/3 cup + teaspoon. I used True Lime & True Lemon powder for 1/3 Cup then used salt for the teaspoon. REALLY good - and lowered the salt (husband's doc told him to lower salt intake - he is not too willing to lower salt - lime and lemon powders are my easiest solution.) 2-26-2018 - this recipe NOW I also make as a gift to friends who LOVE it! I have used simple zip lock plastic bags - to using modest size canning jars - makes a great gift for Tex-Mex enthusiasts!

userID:
2477942
Display Name:
JD
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
76
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only use this taco seasoning recipe and haven't bought it from the grocery store in years.  I don't change the ingredients, but use ground turkey (three pounds 93% lean) and double the taco seasoning recipe.  That a good meat to seasoning ratio.  After I brown the turkey, I drain off the fat, add about one and a half cups of water, add the double taco seasoning, and about a tablespoon of Kitchen Bouquet.  Kitchen Bouquet doesn't add flavor, but does make the turkey meat browner in color, similar to browned ground beef.  I let the turkey simmer on low, uncovered, stirring every few minutes to make sure all of the turkey cooks in the water and spice.  I simmer until almost all of the water has evaporated.  Then it's ready for fantastic tacos - and the best part is that no one will know that it's not ground beef and it's healthier for you and your family.  Thanks Bill for the great recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-10-12T17:28:39.7
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
5417032
Display Name:
potaytou
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
13

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe, but I changed a few things. I doubled the garlic and onion powder to 1/2 tsp each as before the chili powder overwhelmed the other ingredients. I added 1 tsp of corn starch to give the meat a bit of a saucy consistency that the packets normally give. Also, after reading a review by someone stating that they used bouillon cubes to flavor it more, I opted instead to give the meat a splash of soy sauce at the time I added in the spice mix and a bit of water. I didn't want to use something riddled with MSG (which is why I didn't buy the taco seasoning packets in the first place) and bouillon is full of it. I figured I could still get the savory taste from a dash of soy sauce and the meat tasted fantastic!

This whole recipe with the addition of the things I added above, made enough to spice 1 lb of meat. It was slightly more than 3 tbsp worth of spices but I don't mind the meat with a bit more flavor so it tasted great!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I made this recipe because I needed a taco seasoning that was gluten-free. I omitted the red pepper flakes because I have young children. It was still plenty hot. I would likely cut down on the spices when I make it again, but that is just personal preference. I used regular salt and both my husband and I found it way too salty! I can't imagine how salty it would've tasted had I used sea salt. Anyway, I think next time I would cut the salt amount in half, but again, that's just our personal preference.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic!

Added two pinches of superfine sugar (to bring out the robust flavors).  Substituted Smoked Paprika for regular (to give it more of a chipotle feel). 

Take some decent tortilla chips (Donkey Chips, Xochitl), and top them with shredded cheddar and monteray jack cheesees. Sprinkle this wonderful mixture on top and bake for a few min at 350.  Top with a little Cholula and you have a perfect plate of nachos for the 2am munchies!

2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe.  I can never resist tinkering, so I upped the garlic, chili and onion powder about a tsp each, and added about 1/2 tsp more cumin.  I also added a little beef bouillon base.  This helped to cut the chicken flavor since I was using frozen browned ground chicken.  I and added a little water and a little Bud Lite Lime (beer) to give it that 'saucy' texture.  My kids liked it (imagine that) My oldest commented that it was "really good, not just edible but really good" - pretty high praise in my house.  Served it with soft tortillas, fresh avocado, onion, toms, fresh corn off the cob, plus sour cream and cheese all rolled up - excellent dinner!
Review:

5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I made this seasoning. I use it in ground turkey to make taco meat and most people don't know it's not ground beef. This stuff is tasty.   I didn't have any onion powder so I browned the meat with a small minced onion instead and then added 3 tablespoons of seasoning, 2 tablespoons of ketchup and 1/2 cup of water and simmered it until 3/4 of the liquid was gone. Then I added c1/2 teaspoon corn starch to thicken the last of the liquid so it would coat the meat.  It's very good!

text:
I found this recipe because I was looking for an alternative (more natural, less salty) taco seasoning.  I love this recipe as is and I use about 4-5 tablespoons per pound of meat (beef or chicken).  I add about 1/3 c. of water to make it coat the meat better.  I sometimes like a little more heat so I use spicy chili powder or add some cayenne.  But mostly love it as is and will never buy taco seasoning in a packet again!

None
text:
The balance here is fantastic.  I recommend omitting the red pepper flakes if it is too spicy since they are easy for each individual to use at the table to spice things up if needed.  I like my taco meat sort of saucy, so for each recipe (I always make a giant batch - so multiply accordingly!) I add 1 tsp of cornstarch to the mixture.  This thickens whatever liquid you use when simmering and doesn't take away from the fabulous flavor!

text:
I will never, EVER buyh taco seasoning as long as I live.  I love that I can adjust the seasonings to my tastes (I love the smoky flavor of cumin, so I add a little more than the recipe calls for), but that's the beauty of this recipe.  Packets ALWAYS come out too salty for my tastes, but this is taco magic!  Much more authentic flavor, fresher, more robust and accentuates any dish where 'taco' meat is required.  I've used it as a gift idea and even served it up as a Tex-Mex dinner for my brother and his family who live in Maine!  My nieces LOVED it! Thanks!

None
text:
I doubled this using cayenne pepper instead of the red pepper flakes.  Broke up 1 pound ground beef in the crock pot, sprinkled 2tbsp of the seasoning over the meat, poured jar of tomato sauce, 3/4 jar water, large can of drained black beans.  Cooked on high for 2 hours and added 1 bag of success boil in the bag brown rice to the pot and cooked until the rice was done about 20-30 minutes.  Served with shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, crushed tortilla chips.

userID:
2892162
Display Name:
kfcooke
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
48
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a scant tbsp of chili powder, heaping 1/4 tsps of the garlic and onion powders, a heaping 1/4 tsp of paprika, a heaping tsp of cumin, 1/4 tsp of sea salt, a few grinds of fresh black pepper, 1/2 tsp of brown sugar, and 1/4 tsp of unsweetened cocoa powder.  This yielded a very flavorful, mild seasoning.  I then cooked a chopped onion in my pan with a little olive oil until translucent before adding 1 lb of ground beef, which I browned and drained the fat from.  Next I added about 1.5 tbsp of the taco seasoning to the beef, and stirred in 2/3 cup water mixed with 1 tbsp corn starch, which simmered down to make delicious, saucy tacos.  Yummo!

This is an excellent recipe -- you can adjust it to your liking or indredients on hand.  I don't normally have sea salt, so I use regular salt, but use 1/2 of the amount of what is called for with the sea salt.  Also use 1/2 of the black pepper.  I also have added a dash or so of sugar.  Just try this - lots of room for experimenting.

text:
Fantastic! Made this last night because I needed taco seasoning for Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup (Patti). I will not buy the packaged stuff anymore!!! Bill's recipe is pretty straightforward, but I will make a few recommendations that I hope will help everyone else. I CANNOT STRESS ENOUGH HOW IMPORTANT IT IS TO USE THE BEST QUALITY SPICES YOU CAN AFFORD (or find). I live close to a spice shop that sells a variety of reasonably priced spices, so I'm lucky, I guess.... I was able to purchase a few specific ones just for this recipe - Mexican oregano, smoked Hungarian paprika, fresh ground chile pepper, sea salt and a mix of whole peppercorns (I ground fresh pepper specifically for this). All I can say is WOW! My soup was fantastic and I attribute that to using a great spice blend as the base. Try this. You'll be happy you did. :-)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-03-10T21:27:17.79

text:
Excellent recipe.  I made it almost exactly according to the recipe, just added a little more red pepper flakes.  My husband and I like things on the spicy side.  Made a large batch so I always have it ready.  Like the other reviews I used 3 Tbsp seasoning for 1 Lb. ground beef.  I added 2 tsp. cornstarch to 2/3 cup water, mixed well and then added it to the meat and seasoning mixture which gave a nice thickness.  Will pass this recipe on to others, thank you.

text:
This  recipe is SO much better than any taco seasoning mix you'd buy in a packet at the grocery. Since it's prepared from pantry staples, it's an easy matter to mix it up. I quadrupled the recipe and put it in a little storage container with the usage instructions written on the front - I used 3 tablespoons per pound of meat, simmered with half a cup of hot water. Perfect!  My family likes things spicy, so I doubled the amount of red pepper and used cayenne instead of crushed red pepper flakes.

text:
If I could give this 10 stars, I would!  Everyone at the party kept commenting on the flavor of the meat.  It gives it a different taste than the store bought seasonings.  I did cut the crushed red pepper in half.  I browned my meat, drained the fat, then dusted the seasoning over the meat and added 2/3 c water per lb of meat.  I did use about 3 T per lb of meat.  Excellent!!!!  You'll never buy store bought again.

Very good, flavorful, with a good amount of spiciness.  I browned my ground beef with diced onion, green bell pepper and minced garlic (I omitted the onion powder from the recipe); added a generous amount of this seasoning with about 1/3 cup water and let it simmer down.  Worked great, much better than the seasoning packet I usually use, I'm glad I ran out!  I will be using this from now on.

JLAPEZE

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yippeeee Yahoooeeeee!  This recipe is so simple and perfect for tacos.  Especially for kids!!!  I have THE pickiest 9 year old and he even said..."Mom, these are the best tacos you've ever made!"    I sort of feel like Homer Simpson (D'oh) - because I just can't believe after several years of making tacos that I haven't thought to make my own seasonings before.  Recently, I have been trying different brands - just hating the taste - too much salt, too much cumin, too much MSG, artificial flavors, etc.  We have "Taco Tuesday" at our house - and my kids really look forward to it - but last week the store was out of their favorite brand - so I tried the store brand. A disaster - so much sodium that it was just inedible.    Today, I came on here in search of something simple and very tasty.  This is it!!   I made a couple of adjustments for the kids' tacos:  I omitted the crushed red pepper and only put about 1/2 of the salt in - because it's sea salt, I realize that you tend to need more - but I thought I'd give it a shot.  It was just fine.  When my husband and I had our taco salads, I added in the crushed red pepper and it was so great!  I also did what someone else suggested - I combined 2 tablespoons of all purpose flour right into the seasoning mix (prior to adding to the meat), and added 2/3 cup of water.  Again, perfect!  I am so happy to say that I will never buy taco seasoning in the package again!!  Thank you for posting this recipe!!

text:
Perfect! I used all of it for one pound of ground beef. I added it to the raw meat and browned it over medium heat. I drained the fat off and added the meat back into the pan. I then added one 8 oz. can of tomato sauce and let it simmer until it cooked down a little. The tomato sauce just gives it a little more flavor as well as helps the meat stick together a little better for tacos, etc. This is definitely spicy, but we love tex mex!!! You could use less of the spice if you prefer a milder taste. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
For my taste the balance of spices is very good but I deducted a star for being too salty (yes, I used sea salt not table salt). I used an entire recipe for 1 lb of ground meat, but not quite enough of the spices for my taste. I added about 1 tsp cornstarch to browned seasoned meat as suggested by other reviewers, and after sauteing some water and that worked great. Once I tweak those amounts I think I will be much more happy, but I like things strongly flavored. Funny thing is I've used this recipe for the "Slow Cooker Chicken Taco Soup" on this site and found it perfect (oh, except for minus the salt, I added that separately). I'll definitely be keeping this spice blend, I just need to remember to make more "servings" than the default recipe and leave the salt to add separately.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a huge batch of this seasoning mix a while back, and I just love using it to season ground beef for taco salad. It has a ton of flavor, and it beats those MSG-filled packets at the store. I brown some meat (usually 1 to 1.5 pounds) and drain off the fat, sprinkle 3T of this seasoning on top, add in 1 cup of water, cover, and simmer. It couldn't be easier! I like crushing tortilla chips or Doritos on the bottom (yeah, talk about MSG, right?!), putting the meat, some cheese, lettuce, avocado, red onion, tomato, and a big blob of sour cream on top. This spice blend is by far the best I've had. I love it!

text:
I loved this seasoning.  I had all the ingredients on hand and decided to give it a try!!!  It was worth the chance, my new go to seasoning for sure.  It was soooo good and just could not be any easier.  I did take advice from one person that suggested adding a little flour to meat when adding the seasoning (3 TBS per pound of meat)and then when it was coated nicely I added a quarter-cup water per pound of meat.  I let it simmer about ten minutes.  I was using ground venison but I am sure beef is wonderful too.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for years now and it is wonderful. I wanted to make a couple of notes. First, I personally don't use "chili powder" as in chili seasoning, which already has a lot of the same ingredients as this recipe and usually a ton of salt, sometimes fillers, etc., but rather the ground chilis that I find in the Mexican foods section of most grocery stores. They usually have a few different varieties, ranging in degrees of "hotness." Second, if you like this recipe, do yourself a favor and increase the servings to 40 and make a big batch all at once.

text:
My husband liked this, but I did not. It tasted blah and powdery, but this is what I did: Tipped by another reviewer, I added 1/2 Tbsp. flour to 3 Tbsp. of this mix to one pound of ground beef.  After grilling (flour flavor would have well cooked out by this time) I added 2/3 cup water.  I tasted it and decided to add a couple Tbsp. of grated fresh onion to give it some oompf.  It only helped a little.  *Note* some of my spices were old, and that could very well be the problem.

text:
Loved it!  It was a bit spicy for my family but I used cayenne pepper instead of just regular chili powder.  

This is what I did instead:

1 tablespoon Cayenne pepper
1 teaspoon garlic powder 
1 1/4 teaspoon onion powder 
1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes 
1/4 teaspoon dried oregano 
1 teaspoon paprika 
1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin 
1/2 teaspoon black pepper 

Added sea salt to taste. When preparing the tacos, I add one clove fresh garlic and some fresh cilantro (finely minced).

Very good! Followed the recipe exactly, but doubled it for two pounds of ground beef. Added almost 2 cups of water to the browned hamburger, all of the seasoning and simmered for about 20-30 minutes. Cooled and refrigerated over night and used for taco salad the next day! Was great; had just the right "heat" for my family, but that could easily be adjusted according to your own preference. This one is a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe. I fried some mince beef in a tiny bit of oil until brown, drained and rinsed the meat with boiling hot water, put it back in a saucepan, and poured my seasoning over it. I then stirred in about 260ml of cold water and left to simmer for about 40 minutes. When the liquid had gone I stirred in 1 tin of chopped tomatoes and added some salsa and left to simmer for a further 10 minutes. Served in corn tortillas with sour cream, salsa, jalapenoes, lettuce, cheese and fresh chopped tomatoes. Family loved it. Will definately cook this again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the FIRST time that my husband said the homemade version was BETTER than the pre-packaged version.  I whole heartedly agree.  I did add extra garlic because we like it, and reduced the cayenne cause my kids are weenies.  That's the beauty of this stuff, totally customizable to one's tastes!  When I used it, it took about 2 tb for a little less than 1lb of meat.  I added a slurry of 1 tsp cornstarch and about 1/4c water to the pot to get that sauce effect.  This also worked nicely on my Morningstar Farms "grilled chicken" stuff (I don't eat meat), just be careful because the soy or whatever is used to make the fake chicken really pulls in the moisture.

text:
I used this seasoning in the SLOW COOKER CHICKEN TACO SOUP found on this site, it turned out absolutely fantastic, even though there was one spice that didn,t seem to belong. I believe it was the cumin. I will use this seasong again for sure but will either omit or cut down the cumin. It all boils down to ones own personal taste. I would suggest making it without the cumin first then if you decide it is missing something then add it. Easier to add spices to a recipe than to remove.

text:
My husband is the cook in the family and with us being separated for several months, he has been encouraging me to work on my cooking skills and learn more about different spice combinations.  I went to make myself some tacos tonight and found we were out of seasoning packets, so I decided I had to try this seasoning that had such high reviews--and so many of them!  I have to agree that this is a wonderful mix.  I didn't have two of the ingredients, though: onion powder or crushed red pepper.  I used the same measure of dried onions and simply omitted the crushed red pepper.  I thought it was excellent, but those two ingredients are going on my shopping list for next time.  I can't wait to make tacos for my husband again without telling him I've discovered this mix and see what his reaction is.  Thanks! :-D

If I knew it was this easy, I would have been doing it this way for years, rather than run to the store every time I wanted to make tacos.  =)

text:
Pretty good for starters. I also added 2Tbsp. flour, some cayenne pepper, white pepper, paprika, onion salt instead of onion powder,cilantro flakes, a bit more garlic than this called for and finally my special jalapeno powder. Without your recipe as a start I would have had to go to the store in a major snow storm just to buy the package of seasoning.

WOW! I normally have a package or 2 of Williams Taco Seasoning in my cupboard, but this time I didn't and pulled up this recipe. It's PERFECT! I'll NEVER buy this again, there's no need! Thank you for the post! I'm grateful!
